prefix: Ayola says of her film career: "I really like doing film [but] I've not done enough big films though to really know the difference between film and television." Ayola's first prolific television role was in the ITV drama Soldier Soldier, in which she starred throughout its third series in 1993 as soldier's wife Bernie Roberts.
gold: Ayola credits her chemistry with co-star Akim Mogaji, who played her on-screen husband Luke Roberts, for winning her her audition. She went on to appear in Gone With the Wind sequel Scarlett, and star in Welsh soap opera Tiger Bay. She has spoken critically of the way the BBC treated the soap, moving it around the schedules and declining to commission a second series. She acted alongside Pauline Quirke in both Maisie Raine and Being April, deeming Quirke to be a "fantastic" actress, and one she would work alongside again "like a shot". In 1996, Ayola appeared at the National Theatre in Helen Edmundson's adaptation of Leo Tolstoy's War and Peace. In 2001, she became a presenter of the BBC Wales arts programme Double Yellow, alongside poet Owen Sheers and performance artist Mark Rees. She posed nude but for a pair of yellow rubber gloves to promote the show's launch, and was highly critical of the BBC when the show was cancelled midway through its second series. She has since concluded that "the kind of audience they would like to bring in with shows like Double Yellow aren't really into watching TV", but at the time was outspoken against the show's cancellation, stating: Ayola's other notable television appearances include the BBC psychological thriller Green-Eyed Monster (2001), soap opera EastEnders (2001), Waking the Dead (2001), London's Burning (2001), Offenders (2002), Murder in Mind (2003), The Canterbury Tales (2003) and Sea of Souls (2004). In 2008, she starred in the Doctor Who episode "Midnight", playing an intergalactic Hostess alongside David Tennant's Tenth Doctor. In 2009, Ayola starred in the CBBC musical comedy My Almost Famous Family. She stated: "The script made me laugh out loud when I read it. [...] I also like the fact that there were a lot of correct boxes being ticked, but the writers and producer haven't been restrained by that.
text1: After her successful stint on Soldier Soldier, Ayola went on to appear in a string of popular British television dramas, including the BBC's Casualty, where she played the role of nurse Elizabeth Williams from 1995 to 1996. Her talent and versatility as an actress led to her being cast in a number of other notable roles, including a recurring part as DCI Claire Morrison in the ITV police drama The Bill, and a guest appearance as a lawyer in the Channel 4 comedy-drama This Life. In the early 2000s, Ayola made her mark on British television with her portrayal of the complex and troubled character of Rita Hanson in the popular BBC drama Teachers, earning her a nomination for Best Actress at the British Soap Awards. Her film career may have been limited, but Ayola's impressive range and depth as a television actress had established her as a household name in the UK.
text2: As her career in television continued to flourish, Ayola went on to play a wide range of characters, including a villainous sister in the popular BBC sitcom "Fresh Fields" and a strong-willed mother in the ITV drama "Where the Heart Is". Her performances earned her critical acclaim and a loyal fan base. However, it wasn't until she landed the role of DC Stella Mooney in the BBC police procedural "Casualty" in 2002 that she truly found her footing in the industry. She played the character for seven years, earning her a nomination for a TV Quick Award for Best Drama Performance. Throughout her tenure, Ayola worked closely with the show's writers to develop Stella's character, and her performances were widely praised by fans and critics alike.
text3: Ayola's television career thrived as she portrayed various characters, such as a villainous sister in "Fresh Fields" and a strong-willed mother in "Where the Heart Is". She received praise from critics and gained a dedicated following. But it wasn't until she was cast as DC Stella Mooney in the BBC show "Casualty" in 2002 that she really established herself in the field. She portrayed the role for seven years and was nominated for a TV Quick Award for Best Drama Performance. Ayola collaborated with the show's writers to shape Stella's character and received acclaim from both fans and critics for her performances.

prefix: "Exit Through the Kwik-E-Mart" is the fifteenth episode of the twenty-third season of the American animated television sitcom The Simpsons. It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on March 4, 2012.
gold: In the episode, Bart is punished by Homer after letting a rabbit loose in the house. He gets revenge on his father by spray-painting images of him with the word "dope" all over Springfield. Street artist Shepard Fairey encounters Bart one night and offers him a gallery show of Bart's artworks. However, Chief Wiggum suddenly appears during the show and arrests Bart for covering the town in graffiti. It turns out that Fairey is an undercover officer working for Wiggum. The episode references the 2010 street art documentary Exit Through the Gift Shop by graffiti artist Banksy, and features guest appearances from street artists Ron English, Kenny Scharf, and Robbie Conal as themselves.
text1:
The episode begins with Homer's usual morning routine, but instead of rushing to the Springfield Nuclear Power Plant, he's drawn to the Kwik-E-Mart, where Apu is offering a "Buy One, Get One Free" deal on donuts. Homer can't resist and buys a dozen, promptly devouring them all in his car.

Unbeknownst to Homer, his sugar rush sets off a chain reaction of events that lead to chaos in Springfield. As he drives home, he accidentally runs over Mr. Burns' prized garden gnome, "Sir Reginald", causing the evil businessman to declare war on the Simpson family.

Meanwhile, Marge is dealing with her own crisis at the Springfield Elementary School, where she's tasked with organizing a school talent show. Bart and Lisa both sign up, but their performances go awry when they're replaced by a group of unexpected "talent" - a jazz quartet of septuagenarian grandmothers who play the accordion.

As the talent show descends into chaos, Apu's Kwik-E-Mart becomes a hub of activity, with Apu himself struggling to keep up with the demand for donuts and Squishees. Little does he know, Homer's sugar-fueled joyride has attracted the attention of the Springfield Police Department, who are hot on his trail.

In the midst of the mayhem, Marge receives an unexpected phone call from her long-lost sister, Patty, who's returning to Springfield after years away. Patty's got a surprise of her own - a new career as a professional clown - and she's got a surprise gig at the talent show.

As the episode reaches its climax, Homer's sugar-fueled rampage ends in a showdown with the police, while Marge's family and friends gather at the talent show to celebrate (or commiserate) the chaos that's unfolded. Will Apu's Kwik-E-Mart survive the day? Can Marge keep her sanity amidst the bedlam? And what's the deal with Patty's clown career?
text2:
The episode revolves around Apu's Kwik-E-Mart being sold to a wealthy businessman, who decides to turn the corner store into a high-end gourmet market. Homer is heartbroken to see his beloved source for Squishees and stale hot dogs replaced with artisanal cheeses and expensive trinkets.

Determined to save the Kwik-E-Mart's old vibe, Homer organizes a grassroots effort to rally the neighborhood to boycott the upscale mart and support the new owner. Marge and Lisa are skeptical of the plan, but eventually join forces with Homer, who convinces them that the soul of the community is at stake.

Meanwhile, Bart and Krusty the Clown concoct a scheme to cash in on the gentrification of the neighborhood by opening a trendy coffee shop next to the former Kwik-E-Mart location. As the coffee shop, called "Kwik-Cup," becomes a hit with the yuppies, Apu's spirits are lifted, and he sees a glimmer of hope for his beloved store.

Throughout the episode, Homer and his allies employ various stunts to protest against the changes, from attempting to blockade the market with a "Save the Kwik-E-Mart" float to sneaking into the coffee shop to steal the expensive pastry case. However, in the end, Apu comes to accept the changes, realizing that his customers have diversified and that the upscale mart has become a magnet for local food enthusiasts.

The episode concludes with the Simpsons gang enjoying a feast at a newly renovated Apu's Kwik-E-Mart, now hybridized to offer both artisanal cheeses and authentic South Asian snacks. As they savor the fusion of cultures, Homer reflects on the power of community and the need to adapt to the evolving tastes of the neighborhood.
text3: The episode focuses on Apu's Kwik-E-Mart being purchased by a rich businessman, who plans to transform the store into a fancy gourmet market. Homer is devastated to witness the transformation of his favorite spot for Squishees and stale hot dogs into a store selling fancy cheeses and pricey items. Homer leads a community movement to boycott the new upscale market and support the original Kwik-E-Mart vibe. Marge and Lisa initially doubt the idea but later team up with Homer after he persuades them that the essence of the community is in jeopardy. At the same time, Bart and Krusty the Clown come up with a plan to take advantage of the neighborhood's transformation by starting a hip coffee shop near the old Kwik-E-Mart. Apu finds hope for his store as the trendy coffee shop "Kwik-Cup" gains popularity among the yuppies. Homer and his friends use different tactics to protest the changes, such as trying to block the market with a float and sneaking into the coffee shop to steal pastries. Ultimately, Apu embraces the changes and recognizes that his customer base has expanded, with the upscale market attracting local food enthusiasts. The episode ends with the Simpsons group having a meal at the newly remodeled Apu's Kwik-E-Mart, which now offers a mix of artisanal cheeses and traditional South Asian snacks. Homer contemplates the importance of community and adapting to changing neighborhood preferences while enjoying the blend of cultures.

prefix: When he was older, for many years he served as a loyal vassal fighting for his brother, the king of Tikal. Roughly twenty years later, Dos Pilas was attacked by Calakmul and was soundly defeated.
gold: B'alaj Chan K'awiil was captured by the king of Calakmul but, instead of being sacrificed, he was re-instated on his throne as a vassal of his former enemy. He attacked Tikal in 657, forcing Nuun Ujol Chaak, then king of Tikal, to temporarily abandon the city. The first two rulers of Dos Pilas continued to use the Mutal emblem glyph of Tikal, and they probably felt that they had a legitimate claim to the throne of Tikal itself. For some reason, B'alaj Chan K'awiil was not installed as the new ruler of Tikal; instead he stayed at Dos Pilas. Tikal counterattacked against Dos Pilas in 672, driving B'alaj Chan K'awiil into an exile that lasted five years. Calakmul tried to encircle Tikal within an area dominated by its allies, such as El Peru, Dos Pilas, and Caracol. In 682, Jasaw Chan K'awiil I erected the first dated monument at Tikal in 120 years and claimed the title of kaloomte, so ending the hiatus. He initiated a programme of new construction and turned the tables on Calakmul when, in 695, he captured the enemy noble and threw the enemy state into a long decline from which it never fully recovered. After this, Calakmul never again erected a monument celebrating a military victory. By the 7th century, there was no active Teotihuacan presence at any Maya site and the center of Teotihuacan had been razed by 700. Even after this, formal war attire illustrated on monuments was Teotihuacan style. Jasaw Chan K'awiil I and his heir Yik'in Chan K'awiil continued hostilities against Calakmul and its allies and imposed firm regional control over the area around Tikal, extending as far as the territory around Lake Petén Itzá. These two rulers were responsible for much of the impressive architecture visible today.
text1:
The once-proud city of Dos Pilas lay in ruins, its streets littered with the bodies of its brave warriors. The king, who had once fought alongside his brother, the king of Tikal, now sat in defeat, his throne shattered and his people scattered. The armies of Calakmul, led by their ruthless king, had brought destruction upon the city, and its people were forced to flee for their lives.

The king of Dos Pilas, his once-proud heart now heavy with sorrow, sent a message to his brother, the king of Tikal, begging for his aid. He told of the devastating defeat, and of the horrors that had been committed upon his people. He implored his brother to come to his aid, to rally the armies of Tikal and drive the invaders from their lands.

The king of Tikal, still reeling from the loss of his loyal vassal, was shaken by the news. He knew that the defeat of Dos Pilas was a blow not only to his brother, but to the entire kingdom. He knew that he had to act quickly, to rally his armies and march to the aid of his brother and his people.

And so, the king of Tikal set out on the long and perilous journey to Dos Pilas, determined to drive the armies of Calakmul from their lands and restore his brother to his throne.
text2:
The defeat was a devastating blow to Dos Pilas, who was forced to flee with his battered and weary warriors. His thoughts turned to the prophecy of the ancient gods, which had foretold of great calamity befallen the city he loved. As he led his remnants across the scorching landscape, he couldn't shake the feeling that the downfall of Dos Pilas was merely the harbinger of greater troubles to come.

Seeking refuge among the distant Maya cities, Dos Pilas found an unlikely ally in the powerful Lord of Palenque, who was keen to exploit the weakness of Calakmul and expand his own empire. The Lord of Palenque offered Dos Pilas a place at his side, and together they hatched a plan to strike back against their common enemy.

Gathering a fresh force of warriors and stung by his defeat, Dos Pilas led a devastating raid into Calakmul's heartland. The campaign was long and brutal, with Dos Pilas emerging victorious but wounded in spirit and body. His loyalty to the Lord of Palenque had bound him to the throne, but his dreams of returning to the throne of Dos Pilas still burned bright.

Years passed, and Dos Pilas became the sword hand of the Lord of Palenque, carving a path of conquest across Mesoamerica. Yet the memories of Dos Pilas' defeat by Calakmul haunted him still, and his thoughts turned to the prophecy of the ancient gods, wondering when his own fate would unfold, and if the darkness that had befallen him would ever be lifted.
text3: Dos Pilas suffered a crushing defeat and had to escape with his exhausted soldiers. He thought about the ancient gods' prophecy predicting a disaster for his beloved city. While guiding his tired soldiers through the hot terrain, he couldn't help but feel that Dos Pilas' defeat was just the beginning of more challenges ahead. Dos Pilas sought shelter in faraway Maya cities and formed an unexpected alliance with the influential Lord of Palenque, who saw an opportunity to capitalize on Calakmul's vulnerability and grow his empire. The Lord of Palenque extended an invitation to Dos Pilas to join forces and devise a strategy to retaliate against their mutual foe. Dos Pilas, fueled by his defeat, organized a new group of fighters and launched a fierce attack on Calakmul's core territory. After a grueling battle, Dos Pilas emerged triumphant but deeply scarred in both mind and body. Despite his allegiance to the Lord of Palenque, he still held onto the hope of reclaiming the throne of Dos Pilas. Over time, Dos Pilas rose to prominence as a key military leader for the Lord of Palenque, leading successful campaigns throughout Mesoamerica. Dos Pilas continued to be haunted by his defeat at the hands of Calakmul, pondering the prophecy of the ancient gods and questioning when his fate would be revealed and if the darkness surrounding him would ever dissipate.

prefix: However, Stuart concluded that "sometimes in Sonic, when you get better, or through sheer luck, things take off, every jump is right, every loop-the-loop is perfect, and you're in the flow, sailing above the game's strange structure ... Sonic is incorrect game design and yet ... it's a masterpiece." Mega ranked Sonic as its third-favorite Genesis game, and in 2001 Game Informer called it the 24th-greatest game of all time.
gold: Sonic the Hedgehog has been a commercial success; the original Genesis version bundled with the Sega Genesis / Mega Drive hardware had sold over 15 million copies by February 2009, and the mobile version had eight million paid downloads by 2008. Bob Strauss of Entertainment Weekly gave the game an A+ and wrote that it was a very fast game, yet never felt chaotic or impossible, and they later named it the best game available in 1991. Primarily because of its Genesis bundling, Sonic the Hedgehog popularized the console in North America, thus making it a competitor to Nintendo and their Super Nintendo Entertainment System. During October–December 1991, the Genesis outsold the Super NES by two to one; at its January 1992 peak it had 65 percent of the market for 16-bit consoles. Although Nintendo eventually overtook Sega, it was the first time since December 1985 that Nintendo did not lead the console market. Sonic the Hedgehog inspired similar platformers starring animal mascots, including Bubsy, Aero the Acro-Bat, James Pond 3, Earthworm Jim, Zero the Kamikaze Squirrel, and Radical Rex. "Animal with attitude" games carried over to the next generation of consoles, with the developers of Crash Bandicoot and Gex citing Sonic as a major inspiration. Sonic's success led to an extensive media franchise, with the first of many sequels, Sonic the Hedgehog 2, released the following year. It has generated dozens of additional games and a large cast of recurring characters, keeping Sonic and Robotnik (later renamed as Eggman) mainstays, and continued beyond Sega's exit from the console industry after the Dreamcast. The series has ventured from platformers to fighting, racing, role-playing, and sports games, and also expanded into anime, manga, cartoons comic books, novels, and toys. Sonic the Hedgehog is one of the best-selling video game franchises of all time, with over 140 million copies sold or downloaded worldwide across consoles, PC's, mobile phones and tablets by May 2014.
text1:
Despite its unconventional design, Sonic's impact on the gaming industry was undeniable. The game's success spawned a franchise that would go on to include numerous sequels, spin-offs, and merchandise, cementing its place as one of the most iconic and beloved gaming franchises of all time. The game's unique blend of fast-paced action, colorful graphics, and catchy music helped to establish the platformer genre as a staple of the industry, influencing countless other games that would follow in its footsteps.

In the years that followed, Sonic's influence could be seen in games such as Super Mario World, Donkey Kong Country, and even later titles like Rayman Legends and Shovel Knight. The game's emphasis on speed, exploration, and quick reflexes helped to pave the way for the development of new genres, such as the 3D platformer and the speedrun community.

Today, Sonic remains a cultural phenomenon, with new games and adaptations continuing to be released to critical acclaim and commercial success. The game's legacy can be seen in the countless fans who have grown up playing the series, and in the many gamers who continue to discover and enjoy its charms for the first time.

Despite its imperfections, Sonic's influence on the gaming industry is undeniable, and its place as a masterpiece of game design is secure. As Stuart so aptly put it, "it's a masterpiece, and it's a very, very weird one.
text2:
As the years went on, Sonic's cult following only continued to grow. Fans around the world marveled at its sheer speed and sense of freedom, even as critics dismissed it as flawed and shallow. The game's enduring popularity sparked a fervent debate among gamers, with some insisting that its quirks and shortcomings were a crucial part of its charm. Despite its mechanical issues and obtuse level design, Sonic retained a peculiar charm that captivated players of all ages.

By the time of Sonic's tenth anniversary in 2001, the series had expanded to encompass dozens of spin-off games, TV shows, and comics. Yet amidst all the chaos and franchising frenzy, the original 16-bit sensation remained an iconic, beloved classic – a testament to the power of grassroots gaming enthusiasm. As fans gazed upon Sonic in all his blue and white glory, they couldn't help but remember the countless hours spent exploring Green Hill Zone, the countless mid-air jumps, and the countless infuriating deaths that only made the sweet moments of triumph all the sweeter.
text3: Over time, Sonic's dedicated fan base kept expanding. Fans worldwide admired Sonic's speed and freedom, despite critics labeling it as flawed and lacking depth. Gamers passionately argued that the game's imperfections were essential to its appeal. Sonic's unique charm continued to captivate players of all ages, despite its flaws in gameplay and level design. By 2001, Sonic's tenth anniversary saw the series grow to include numerous spin-off games, TV shows, and comics. Despite all the expansion and diversification of the franchise, the original 16-bit game remained a beloved classic, showcasing the influence of grassroots gaming passion. Fans fondly reminisced about their time playing Sonic, recalling the hours spent in Green Hill Zone, the exhilarating mid-air jumps, and the frustrating deaths that made victories even more satisfying.

prefix: U.S. Gold acquired the rights to make a version of Sonic the Hedgehog for the Amiga, ZX Spectrum, Commodore 64, Amstrad CPC and Atari ST personal computers, but these went unreleased. Several screenshots exist, some of which resemble the 8-bit version.
gold: An enhanced port for the Sega CD was also planned, but was scrapped in favor of Sonic CD. Sonic the Hedgehog was praised by critics, with an 86% rating at the review aggregator GameRankings. It was considered Sega's answer to Nintendo's widely popular Mario series, as it was a platformer featuring the company's mascot. Paul Rand of Computer and Video Games compared the two in depth and characterized Sonic the Hedgehog as being faster, with brighter colors, and Super Mario World as having more "depth of play". Frank Ladoire of believed Sonic the Hedgehog was part of a new generation of games that demonstrate that the Genesis is capable of "beautiful things" in the technical department. Reviewers praised the colorful, detailed graphics. Rand called its color scheme "lively, but never garish", praising the interaction of color with detail in the sprites, backgrounds, and animations and describing its graphics as the best available for the Genesis. Reviewer Boogie Man of GamePro called the intricate backgrounds "eye-popping" and "gorgeous", which was echoed by Mean Machines. The Lessers (Hartley, Patricia, and Kirk) of Dragon claimed the graphics made Sonic a possible contender for the best game of 1991 and GameZone called the animation "some of the smoothest and fastest ... ever seen". Julian Boardman of Raze praised the "colourful and highly detailed" backdrops and "fabulous" sprites. The music and sound effects were also well received; Dragon called them "great", and GameZone "amazing". Rand praised the "catchy" soundtrack, calling some of the sound effects "absolutely brilliant". Although Mean Machines called the songs "vaguely appealing", the sound effects were better appreciated. However, Boardman of Raze considered the music "a little boring". Critics cited the fast gameplay, unprecedented in platformers. The difficulty was disputed, described as "impossible" by Rand and "average" by EGM. Rand said about the gameplay in general that it "plays like a dream"; according to GameZone it would enchant players for hours, and Boogie Man praised Sonic Team's ability to provide an engaging experience primarily from running and jumping.
text1:
Despite the existence of the screenshots and pre-release material, the exact fate of these Sonic the Hedgehog versions remains shrouded in mystery. It is unclear why U.S. Gold ultimately decided not to release the games, but it is believed that the company's resources were redirected to other projects or that the development was abandoned due to technical challenges.

Rumors and speculation have circulated among retro gaming enthusiasts over the years, with some suggesting that the Amiga version was nearly complete before being scrapped, while others claim that the game was never actually playable in any form.

In recent years, a small number of enthusiasts have attempted to recreate the lost versions of Sonic the Hedgehog using publicly available resources, such as the original game's code and graphics. These efforts have yielded interesting and sometimes convincing results, giving fans a glimpse into what could have been.

However, the true extent of the development process remains unknown, and the original creators and developers involved have largely remained silent on the topic. The Sonic the Hedgehog games that were ultimately released in the late 1980s and early 1990s on other platforms, such as the Sega Genesis and Master System, went on to become beloved classics, leaving the abandoned Amiga and 8-bit versions as a fascinating footnote in the history of the iconic character.
text2:
As the years went by, the existence of the cancelled Sonic the Hedgehog port for these retro computers became the stuff of legends among gamers and historians of the industry. The few screenshots that survived became iconic, symbolizing a "what if" scenario for many.

In recent years, a small but dedicated group of enthusiasts, including some of the original team members, have come forward to share their stories and experiences about the project. According to an interview with a former developer, the team had to heavily compress the game's data to fit it within the limited storage capacity of the 8-bit computers, leading to a lack of polish and numerous technical issues.

Additionally, the team faced difficulty recreating the lightning-fast gameplay and colorful graphics of the Mega Drive original on the older hardware. The project was eventually shelved, and the remaining assets were destroyed, or so it seemed.

Recently, a mysterious collector claimed to possess the last surviving prototype of the cancelled Sonic the Hedgehog port for the Commodore Amiga. The collector, who wished to remain anonymous, shared some tantalizing details, including a claim that the game would have featured a unique "touch-sensitive" interface for the Amiga's mouse, allowing players to control Sonic in new and innovative ways.

As news of the alleged prototype's existence spread, retro gaming enthusiasts around the world began clamoring to learn more. While the truth behind the collector's claim remains to be seen, the allure of the lost and unfinished project continues to captivate gamers, serving as a reminder that even the most obscure aspects of video game history can hold a certain charm.
text3: Over time, the cancelled Sonic the Hedgehog port for retro computers became legendary among gamers and industry historians. The surviving screenshots became symbols of a hypothetical scenario for many. Recently, a committed group of fans, including original team members, have emerged to discuss their involvement in the cancelled Sonic the Hedgehog port for retro computers. In an interview with a former developer, it was revealed that the team had to compress the game's data significantly to make it compatible with the limited storage capacity of 8-bit computers, resulting in a lack of refinement and various technical problems. Moreover, the team struggled to replicate the high-speed gameplay and vibrant visuals of the original Mega Drive version on the outdated hardware. The project was ultimately abandoned, and it appeared that the remaining assets were destroyed. A collector recently came forward claiming to have the only remaining prototype of the cancelled Sonic the Hedgehog port for the Commodore Amiga. The collector, who preferred not to reveal their identity, disclosed intriguing information about the cancelled Sonic the Hedgehog port, such as the inclusion of a special "touch-sensitive" interface for the Amiga's mouse. Retro gaming fans worldwide eagerly sought more information as word of the prototype's existence circulated. The mystery surrounding the collector's assertion still lingers, but the fascination with the unfinished project remains strong, highlighting the enduring appeal of obscure video game history.

prefix: In June 1994, the United Keetoowah Band had voted to stop awarding associate memberships. Such honorary associate membership recognizes an individual's assistance to the tribe, but it has nothing to do with Indian ancestry, and it does not entitle an individual to vote in the tribe as a member.
gold: The Keetoowah Band states that Churchill still holds the associate membership and it has not been rescinded. In a separate interview, Ernestine Berry, formerly on the tribe's enrollment committee and four years on its council, said that Churchill had never fulfilled a promise to help the tribe. In June 2005, the Rocky Mountain News published an article about Churchill's genealogy and family history. The newspaper's research "turned up no evidence of a single Indian ancestor" among 142 direct ancestors [of Churchill's] identified from records. The News reported that both Churchill's birth parents were listed as white on the 1930 census, as were all but two of his great-great-grandparents listed on previous census and other official documents. The News found that some of Churchill's accounts of where his ancestors had lived did not agree with documented records. Numerous members of Churchill's extended family have longstanding family legends of Indian ancestry among ancestors; but, none was confirmed among the 142 direct forebears of Churchill who were identified. Documents in Churchill's university personnel file show that he was granted tenure in a "special opportunity position". In 1994, then CU-Boulder Chancellor James Corbridge refused to take action on allegations that Churchill was fraudulently claiming to be an Indian, saying "it has always been university policy that a person's race or ethnicity is self-proving." Some of Churchill's Native American critics, such as Vernon Bellecourt (White Earth Ojibwe) and Suzan Shown Harjo (Southern Cheyenne-Muscogee Creek), argue that his assertion of Native American ancestry without the ability to prove it might constitute misrepresentation and grounds for termination. The University has said that it does not hire on the basis of ethnicity. The University of Colorado's Research Misconduct Committee conducted a preliminary investigation into whether Churchill misrepresented his ethnicity to "add credibility and public acceptance to his scholarship". The committee concluded that the allegation was not "appropriate for further investigation under the definition of research misconduct". In a 2005 interview in The Rocky Mountain News, Churchill said, "I have never been confirmed as having one-quarter blood, and never said I was. And even if [the critics] are absolutely right, what does that have to do with this issue?
text1:
As a result of this decision, the United Keetoowah Band began to focus on clarifying the tribe's membership rules and regulations. In the following months, the tribe worked to establish a more defined process for verifying the ancestry of potential members. This effort aimed to ensure that only individuals who could demonstrate a direct ancestral connection to the Keetoowah Cherokee people would be eligible for full membership in the tribe.

In October 1994, the tribe published its new membership ordinance, which outlined the specific requirements for establishing Keetoowah Cherokee ancestry. The ordinance emphasized the importance of documenting genealogical records, including birth and death certificates, census data, and other historical documents. The tribe also established a formal membership application process, which required applicants to provide extensive documentation to support their claims of Keetoowah Cherokee ancestry.

Over the next several years, the United Keetoowah Band continued to refine its membership process, working to ensure that its membership rolls accurately reflected the tribe's ancestral connections. While this effort presented challenges, the tribe's leaders believed that it was essential to maintain the integrity and legitimacy of the tribe's membership rolls. By the early 2000s, the tribe had successfully implemented its new membership process, and the number of confirmed members had stabilized. The United Keetoowah Band's focus on verifying its ancestry had helped to establish a stronger sense of tribal identity and unity among its members.
text2:
The decision to discontinue awarding associate memberships was a result of the United Keetoowah Band's efforts to streamline its membership process and ensure that only those with a proven cultural and ancestral tie to the tribe could claim membership. The band's enrollment committee worked tirelessly to review and verify the lineage of potential members, verifying their ancestry through a thorough research process. This change in policy was seen as a crucial step in preserving the cultural integrity and heritage of the United Keetoowah Band, and was widely supported by its enrolled members.

In the years following the policy change, the band continued to focus on revitalizing and promoting its rich cultural traditions. The community center in Westville, Oklahoma, where the band is headquartered, became a hub for arts and crafts, language preservation, and traditional music and dance. The band's youth were actively encouraged to learn and practice these traditional skills, with the hope of passing them down to future generations.

Meanwhile, the United Keetoowah Band also expanded its efforts to promote cultural education and awareness among the broader community. The band's cultural museum was established in the late 1990s, featuring exhibits on the tribe's history, traditions, and way of life. The band's artists also began participating in cultural festivals and exhibitions around the country, sharing their unique crafts and traditions with a wider audience.

Today, the United Keetoowah Band is a thriving community, proud of its heritage and its continued commitment to preserving and promoting its rich cultural traditions.
text3: The United Keetoowah Band decided to stop giving out associate memberships in order to simplify the membership process and verify that only those with a genuine cultural and ancestral connection to the tribe could become members. The enrollment committee diligently researched the lineage of potential members to confirm their ancestry. The decision to limit memberships to those with genuine cultural and ancestral connections was widely backed by the tribe's current members as a key move to protect their cultural integrity and heritage. Over time, the band remained dedicated to reviving and showcasing its diverse cultural customs. The community center in Westville, Oklahoma, served as a central location for promoting arts, language preservation, and traditional cultural activities. Young members of the band were encouraged to learn and practice traditional skills in order to preserve them for future generations. Additionally, the United Keetoowah Band increased its initiatives to raise awareness and educate the wider community about their culture. In the late 1990s, the band opened a cultural museum that showcased the tribe's history, traditions, and way of life. The band's artists expanded their reach by showcasing their crafts and traditions at cultural events nationwide. Presently, the United Keetoowah Band is a flourishing community that takes pride in its heritage and ongoing efforts to safeguard and celebrate its diverse cultural customs.

prefix: Ward LeRoy Churchill (born 1947) is an American author and political activist. He was a professor of ethnic studies at the University of Colorado Boulder from 1990 until 2007.
gold: The primary focus of his work is on the historical treatment of political dissenters and Native Americans by the United States government. His work features controversial and provocative views, written in a direct, often confrontational style. In January 2005, Churchill's 2001 essay "On the Justice of Roosting Chickens" gained attention. In the work, he argued the September 11 attacks were a natural and unavoidable consequence of unlawful U.S. foreign policy over the latter half of the 20th century; the essay is known for Churchill's use of the phrase "little Eichmanns" to describe the "technocratic corps" working in the World Trade Center. In March 2005, the University of Colorado began investigating allegations that Churchill had engaged in research misconduct; it reported in June 2006 that he had done so. Churchill was fired on July 24, 2007, leading to a claim by some scholars that he was fired because of the "Little Eichmanns" comment. Churchill filed a lawsuit against the University of Colorado for unlawful termination of employment. In April 2009 a Denver jury found that Churchill was unjustly fired, awarding him $1 in damages. In July 2009, a District Court judge vacated the monetary award and declined Churchill's request to order his reinstatement, deciding the university has "quasi-judicial immunity".
text1:
Ward Churchill's academic career was marked by controversy and criticism, particularly in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks. In 2005, he sparked outrage when he wrote an essay titled "On the Justice of Roosting Chickens," which some interpreted as justifying the 9/11 attacks. The university subsequently launched an investigation into Churchill's work, and in 2006, the Board of Regents stripped him of his tenure and placed him on administrative leave. The controversy surrounding Churchill's writings and academic practices led to a fierce debate about academic freedom and the limits of free speech.

Despite the controversy, Churchill continued to write and speak out on various social and political issues, including Native American rights, anti-war activism, and critical pedagogy. He has published numerous books and articles, including "And Yet They Come: Jubilant Dispatches from the Wakarusa Warrior Council" and "Pacifism as Pathology: Reflections on the Role of Anti-War Movements." Churchill has also been a vocal critic of the US government and its foreign policies, particularly with regards to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

In recent years, Churchill has been involved in various legal and political battles, including a lawsuit against the University of Colorado Boulder alleging retaliation and defamation. Despite the challenges he has faced, Churchill remains a prominent figure in the world of academia and activism, known for his provocative writings and unwavering commitment to social justice and human rights.
text2: Ward Churchill, a renowned critic of U.S. foreign policy and Native American policy, gained widespread attention and controversy for his article "Some Peoples Law" published in the Chronicle of Higher Education in 2005, in which he argued that the September 11th attacks on the World Trade Center were a natural response to the violence and injustice perpetuated by the United States against the people of Afghanistan and Iraq. His statements sparked heated debates among scholars, activists, and policymakers, leading to both strong criticisms and support from various quarters. As a result, Churchill became a lightning rod for public attention and was eventually terminated from his job at the University of Colorado Boulder in 2007 amidst a contentious investigation into his scholarly credentials and alleged plagiarism. Despite the controversy surrounding his work, Churchill remains an important voice in the academic and activist communities, continuing to write and speak out on issues related to globalization, colonialism, and social justice.
text3: Ward Churchill, a well-known critic of U.S. foreign policy and Native American policy, sparked controversy with his article "Some Peoples Law" in 2005, where he argued that the September 11th attacks were a result of U.S. violence and injustice towards Afghanistan and Iraq. His comments ignited intense discussions among academics, advocates, and government officials, resulting in both harsh critiques and endorsements from different groups. Due to the controversy surrounding his views, Ward Churchill attracted significant public scrutiny and was fired from his position at the University of Colorado Boulder in 2007 following a controversial investigation into his academic qualifications and accusations of plagiarism. Even with the backlash he faced, Churchill continues to be a significant figure in academic and activist circles, advocating for issues like globalization, colonialism, and social justice.

prefix: As a result, he was promoted to the Ministry of Personnel and gained admittance to the Hanlin Academy, but before he could take up this appointment, Beijing had fallen to the Manchu rebellion. Since contemporaneous biographies (Wen's work was not published until 1830) make no mention of these events, it has been suggested that they were fabricated after Hu's death.
gold: Hu retired from public life and went into seclusion in 1646, after the end of the Ming dynasty. Xiao Yuncong and Lü Liuliang recorded visiting him during his later years, in 1667 and 1673 respectively. He died in poverty at the age of 90, sometime around late 1673 or early 1674. Hu Zhengyan was a noted seal-carver, producing personal seals for numerous dignitaries. His style was rooted in the classical seal script of the Han dynasty, and he followed the Huizhou school of carving founded by his contemporary He Zhen. Hu's calligraphy, although balanced and with a clear compositional structure, is somewhat more angular and rigid than the classical models he followed. Huizhou seals attempt to impart an ancient, weathered impression, although unlike other Huizhou artists Hu did not make a regular practice of artificially aging his seals. Hu's work was known outside his local area. Zhou Lianggong, a poet who lived in Nanjing around the same time as Hu and was a noted art connoisseur, stated in his Biography of Seal-Carvers (Yinren Zhuan, ) that Hu "creates miniature stone carvings with ancient seal inscriptions for travellers to fight over and treasure", implying that his carvings were popular with visitors and travellers passing through Nanjing. In 1644, Hu took it upon himself to create a new Imperial seal for the Hongguang Emperor, which he carved after a period of fasting and prayer. He presented his creation with an essay, the Great Exhortation of the Seal (Dabao Zhen, ), in which he bemoaned the loss of the Chongzhen Emperor's seal and begged Heaven's favour in restoring it. Hu was concerned that his essay would be overlooked because he had not written it in the form of rhyming, equally-footed couplets (pianti, ) used in the Imperial examinations, but his submission and the seal itself were nevertheless both accepted by the Southern Ming court.
text1:
Despite the uncertainty surrounding his early career, Hu's fate became shrouded in mystery after Beijing's fall to the Manchu rebellion. Some accounts suggest that he was forced to flee the city, leaving behind his family and possessions, while others claim that he was captured by the enemy and never heard from again. The Hanlin Academy, once a symbol of his academic and professional aspirations, was now under the control of the invading forces.

Years went by, and the news of Hu's disappearance was gradually forgotten, overshadowed by the turmoil and upheaval that followed the rebellion. It wasn't until decades later, when Wen, a distant relative of Hu's, began compiling his biography, that the story of his life was revived. Wen's account, published in 1830, provided a detailed and vivid portrayal of Hu's life, including his alleged promotion to the Ministry of Personnel and his admittance to the Hanlin Academy.

However, the veracity of Wen's account has been called into question by many scholars, who point out the lack of contemporary evidence to support these claims. Some have even speculated that Wen, driven by a desire to elevate his own family's reputation, fabricated the entire narrative. As a result, Hu's life remains shrouded in mystery, leaving historians to continue their search for the truth about this enigmatic figure from China's troubled past.
text2:
The question of whether Hu Yinglin's early career events were fabricated or not had plagued scholars for centuries. As the debate continued to swirl, a team of archaeologists stumbled upon a hidden chamber deep within the ancient walls of the Hanlin Academy. As they carefully excavated the dusty relics, they uncovered a cryptic scroll, penned in the exact hand of Hu Yinglin himself.

Unraveling the complex script, the team discovered that the scroll was a draft of Hu's proposed autobiography, penned during the tumultuous period just before Beijing fell to the Manchu rebellion. The contents of the scroll blew apart the theory of fabricated events, painting a vivid picture of Hu's struggles to secure his promotion and his tumultuous ride into the midst of the rebellion's devastation.

The scroll's findings sent shockwaves through the academic community, with many scholars reevaluating their understanding of Hu's life and times. As the truth began to come to light, a new wave of intrigue washed over Hu Yinglin's enigmatic persona: what else had the mysterious scholar hidden beneath the surface?
text3: Scholars have been troubled for centuries by the debate over whether Hu Yinglin's early career events were made up. While the debate persisted, archaeologists unexpectedly discovered a secret chamber within the Hanlin Academy's ancient walls. While digging through the artifacts, they found a mysterious scroll written by Hu Yinglin. Deciphering the intricate writing, the group found that the scroll was a rough version of Hu's autobiography, written during the chaotic time right before Beijing was taken over by the Manchu rebellion. The scroll revealed the truth about Hu Yinglin's challenges in seeking promotion and his involvement in the rebellion's chaos. The discovery of the scroll caused a significant reevaluation among scholars regarding Hu Yinglin's life and historical context. With the revelation of the truth, curiosity grew about what other secrets Hu Yinglin may have concealed.

prefix: After completing the song, Carey changed to a pair of leg-hugging blue jeans and a tank top. Her next performance was the "Fantasy" remix, featuring Ol' Dirty Bastard on a large projection screen behind the stage, as Carey performed light chair dance-routines alongside several male dancers.
gold: The performance featured the most intricate choreography Carey performed on the tour. After a low-key performance of "Babydoll", or "Whenever You Call" in other countries, Carey was once again joined by several male dancers, as she sang "Honey", while re-enacting the music video during a small skit. Carey once again changed to a beige ensemble similar to her first outfit before performing her debut single, "Vision of Love". The final song on the tour was "Butterfly", which featured large stills of butterflies and flowers projected onto the large screen behind Carey. She donned a long brown sequined gown for the performance, being joined on stage once again by her trio of back-up singers. During the shows in Japan, Carey performed her holiday classic "All I Want for Christmas Is You", alongside various male and female dancers on stage who performed light dance routines alongside Carey. During the song, Carey donned a Santa suit and matching hat, while being carried on a large stage prop by the dancers. The show at Hawaii's 50,000 capacity Aloha Stadium made her one of the few acts in the stadium's history to sell out the entire venue. Aside from its commercial success, fans and critics raved about the show's visuals, as well as Carey's vocal delivery. During the tour, several bits and performances were filmed and later edited into a VHS and DVD entitled Around the World. The VHS featured performances from Tokyo Dome, Aloha Stadium as well as few other skits and scenes that were later compiled into the video. The film first begins with performances in Hawaii, where the song's recitals are cut into halves, excluding the second verses and bridge to shorten the bulk length of the video. Afterwards, Carey's performance of "My All" is shown in inter-cut scenes from Japan and Taipei. After the conclusion of the song, scenes of Carey conversing with Brenda K. Starr are shown, which eventually lead to a tribute to her at a small and intimate New York club, where Carey performs "I Still Believe". Soon after, Carey's performance in Japan with Lorenz for "I'll Be There" is shown, leading to scenes of Carey swimming with dolphins in Australia.
text1:
As the beat dropped on "Fantasy", the crowd erupted into cheers and applause. Carey's dancers, clad in sleek black outfits, moved in perfect sync with her, their bodies weaving in and out of the pulsating lights that scanned the stage. Meanwhile, Ol' Dirty Bastard's distinctive voice boomed through the speakers, his lyrics spitting bars that had the audience singing along in unison.

Carey herself was a whirlwind of energy, spinning and twirling across the stage in her blue jeans and tank top. She seemed to defy gravity, her long legs kicking out in rhythmic precision as she danced atop a raised platform, the dancers surrounding her like a human vortex.

As the song reached its climax, Carey leapt off the platform, landing in a pose that showcased her toned physique. The crowd went wild, screaming and whistling as she struck a series of sultry poses, her eyes gleaming with a fierce intensity. For a moment, it seemed as though she was the queen of the night, the star of the show, and the audience was hers to command.
text2:
As the remix reached its climax, Carey flailed her arms and tossed her head, her long hair flying out in all directions. The dancers surrounding her responded in kind, their movements becoming more frantic and sensual. The audience erupted in cheers, screaming along to the lyrics as Carey's voice soared through the complex rhythms.

When "Fantasy" finally faded out, Carey segued directly into her signature hit, "We Belong Together". She launched into the song's opening lines, her vocal range effortlessly spanning the wide range required. The audience sang along in unison, waving their hands in the air as the dancers on stage mirrored the emotions conveyed by Carey's music.

But just as the song was reaching its peak, a surprise addition joined Carey on stage. The drummer from Maroon 5, who had been hiding backstage waiting for his cue, emerged from behind the curtains and launched into a frenetic drum solo. Carey, unfazed, adjusted her mic stand to accommodate the sudden change in arrangement and took a step forward, her eyes locked on the crowd.

The mashup of styles caught the audience off guard, but it only added to the electricity in the room. The energy was electric, with the crowd singing along to "We Belong Together", and Carey's voice mingling with the driving drums. As the song finally began to wind down, Carey drew her mic stand back to her lips and delivered a final, triumphant note, the crowd erupting into applause as the band came together for a final, thunderous chord.
text3: During the peak of the remix, Carey waved her arms and shook her head, causing her long hair to fly in different directions. The dancers mirrored her energy, moving with increased intensity and sensuality. The crowd cheered loudly and sang along enthusiastically as Carey's powerful voice carried through the intricate beats. After finishing "Fantasy", Carey smoothly transitioned into her popular song "We Belong Together". She effortlessly began singing the opening lines, showcasing her wide vocal range. The crowd joined in singing and dancing along with the performers, matching the emotions of Carey's music. However, as the song was building up to its climax, a unexpected guest appeared on stage with Carey. The drummer from Maroon 5 suddenly appeared on stage and began an energetic drum solo after waiting backstage for his cue. Carey remained composed and adapted to the new arrangement by adjusting her microphone stand and confidently stepping closer to the audience. The unexpected combination of styles surprised the audience, but it enhanced the energy in the room. The atmosphere was charged as the audience sang along to "We Belong Together" while Carey's vocals intertwined with the powerful drumming. Carey ended the song with a powerful note, prompting the crowd to cheer as the band played a final chord.

prefix: On January 19, Michigan became the leader in the conference with a 5–2 record, thanks to conference wins over ranked Wisconsin and Michigan State teams. Michigan remained in first place until losing to Ohio State ten days later.
gold: The team went 5–2 in conference in February, including wins over ranked Indiana and Ohio State teams. Michigan lost its final home game of the season to Purdue on February 25 to finish with a 15–1 home record. On March 1, the team defeated Illinois for their first road win in Illinois since 1995. During the game, Michigan's 30th of the season, Trey Burke broke Gary Grant's school freshman assists record, set over the course of 30 games in the 1984–85 season, by pushing his total to 143. The March 4 victory over Penn State clinched a share of the 2011–12 Big Ten Conference season regular season championship. In the first game of the 2012 Big Ten Conference Men's Basketball Tournament against Minnesota, Burke led the team to victory with a career-high 30 points. Burke's total was a school record for the Big Ten Conference Men's Basketball Tournament. In the semifinal contest, however, Michigan was eliminated by Ohio State for the third year in a row. Michigan entered the 2012 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament seeded fourth, but lost to the thirteenth-seeded Ohio Bobcats 65–60. Burke became Michigan's first Associated Press All-American honoree since Robert Traylor and Louis Bullock in 1998. Stu Douglass concluded the season as the school's all-time leader in games played, with 136. He surpassed Loy Vaught, who played in 135 games. Novak set the school record in career minutes played with 4,357, surpassing Louis Bullock, who played 4,356 minutes. Burke had a school record-setting freshman season in assists, ending the year with 156. Five of the 30 nominees for the men's basketball Lowe's Senior CLASS Award were from the Big Ten, including Michigan's Zack Novak. Trey Burke was one of nearly 60 Bob Cousy Award candidates named in December 2011. On January 4, Burke was one of 20 finalists. On January 25, Novak was named one of ten finalists for the Lowe's Senior CLASS Award along with three other Big Ten athletes. He was also one of four Big Ten men's basketball players named Academic All-District, putting him among the 40 finalists for the 15-man Academic All-America team. Novak was named a third team Academic All-American. The team lost senior captains Stu Douglass and Zack Novak as well as senior reserve Corey Person to graduation following the season. Person was later granted an extra year of eligibility to return to the team.
text1: However, Michigan's brief reign at the top of the conference was short-lived. The Wolverines bounced back from their loss to Ohio State with a crucial 3-2 win over Penn State on February 1, which kept them within striking distance of the top spot. As the regular season drew to a close, Michigan found themselves tied with Ohio State for first place, with the Buckeyes holding a single point advantage. The Wolverines would need to win their final two games of the regular season to have any chance at capturing the conference title.
text2: The loss to Ohio State snapped Michigan's seven-game win streak and sent them stumbling into a crucial stretch against top-ranked opponents. Over the next four weeks, the Wolverines faced a gauntlet of high-powered programs, including a road trip to Iowa, a showdown with undefeated Purdue, and a battle against arch-rivals Illinois in Ann Arbor. Despite the tough schedule, Michigan refused to give up ground and managed to eke out three consecutive wins, including a thrilling 65-60 victory over Iowa in triple overtime. The victories propelled the Wolverines back into first place, where they would remain for the next five weeks, riding a six-game win streak.
text3: Michigan's seven-game win streak was ended by Ohio State, causing them to struggle against top-ranked opponents in a crucial stretch. Michigan faced tough opponents in the following weeks, such as Iowa, Purdue, and Illinois. Michigan persevered through a challenging schedule and secured three straight wins, including a thrilling triple-overtime victory against Iowa. Michigan's wins put them in first place for five weeks with a six-game win streak.

prefix: In addition, a battery of four 105mm howitzers from the 3rd Battalion, 11th Marine Regiment under Lieutenant colonel James J. Keating moved to a location from where it could provide direct fire onto the ridge, and a forward artillery observer was placed with Edson's front line units. Late in the afternoon, Edson stepped onto a grenade box and addressed his exhausted troops, saying, Edson's speech "raised the spirits" of the Raiders and helped them prepare mentally for the night ahead.
gold: As the sun set on 13 September, Kawaguchi faced Edson's 830 Marines with 3,000 troops of his brigade, plus an assortment of light artillery. The night was pitch black, with no moon. At 21:00, seven Japanese destroyers briefly bombarded the ridge. Kawaguchi's attack began just after nightfall, with Kokusho's battalion assaulting Raider Company B on the Marine right flank, just to the west of the ridge. The force of the assault caused Company B to fall back to Hill 123. Under Marine artillery fire, Kokusho reassembled his men and continued his attack. Without pausing to try to "roll-up" the other nearby Marine units, whose flanks were now unprotected, Kokusho's unit surged forward through the swampy lowlands between the ridge and the Lunga River, heading for the airfield. Kokusho's men came upon a pile of Marine supplies and rations. Not having eaten adequately for a couple of days, they paused to "gorge themselves" on the "C" and "K" rations. Kokusho ordered his men to continue the attack. At about 03:00, he led them against the Marine units around the northern portion of the ridge, just short of the airfield, as well as Hill 123. In the heavy fighting that followed, Kokusho and around 100 of his men were killed, ending that attack. Meanwhile, Kawaguchi's 2nd Battalion, under Major Masao Tamura, assembled for their planned assault against Hill 80 from the jungle south of the ridge. Marine observers spotted Tamura's preparations and called in artillery fire. At about 22:00, a barrage from twelve guns hit Tamura's position. In response, two companies of Tamura's troops—numbering about 320 men—charged up Hill 80 with fixed bayonets behind their own barrage of mortar fire and grenades.
text1:
As the sun dipped below the horizon, casting a golden glow over the battlefield, Edson's Raiders settled in for a long and uncertain night. The forward artillery observer, a burly sergeant with a calm demeanor, radioed back to the battery of howitzers, his voice steady as he guided the firing solution for the 105mm rounds. The Raiders, weary but resolute, took up positions behind their makeshift defensive line, their eyes scanning the darkness for any sign of the enemy.

Edson, still energized from his impromptu speech, moved quietly along the line, checking on his men and offering words of encouragement. He knew that the coming night would be brutal, with the Japanese trying to exploit the darkness to launch a surprise attack. But he also knew that his Raiders were ready, their training and experience honed to a fine edge.

As the stars began to twinkle overhead, the air grew heavy with anticipation. The Raiders could feel it, a palpable sense of tension that seemed to vibrate through the very earth itself. They knew that the Japanese were out there, waiting for the perfect moment to strike. And Edson knew that his men were ready to meet them head-on.
text2: As the last light of day faded from the mountainous horizon, Edson's exhausted Raiders settled in for a restless night, their minds racing with the thought of the battle to come. The sounds of Japanese artillery echoed through the valleys, a constant reminder that the enemy was still out there, waiting for them. The Raiders' positions were taken up with a mix of weary men, some dozing off fitfully while others remained wide-eyed and alert, waiting for the first sign of the Japanese attack. Despite the fatigue, Edson's speech still resonated with them, and they felt a newfound sense of purpose and determination wash over them. As they settled in for the night, the Raiders knew that the battle to take Mt. Austen would be fierce and intense, but they also knew that they had what it took to come out on top.
text3: After the sun disappeared behind the mountains, Edson's tired Raiders prepared for a sleepless night, anxiously anticipating the upcoming battle. The constant echoes of Japanese artillery served as a reminder that the enemy was still present and waiting. The Raiders were stationed with a combination of exhausted soldiers, some drifting in and out of sleep while others stayed awake and vigilant, ready for the Japanese assault. Even though they were tired, Edson's words inspired them and they felt a renewed sense of resolve. The Raiders were aware that the fight for Mt. Austen would be tough, but they were confident in their ability to emerge victorious.

prefix: John Luther Adams, composer; although more associated with Alaska, he was born in Meridian Susan Akin, who won the Miss America beauty pageant in 1986 John Besh, New Orleans cuisine chef, TV personality, philanthropist, restaurateur and author Gil Carmichael, Meridian businessman, transportation specialist, and politician, was the Republican nominee for the Mississippi Senate in 1966 and 1967, U.S. Senate in 1972, governor in 1975 and 1979, and lieutenant governor in 1983 James Chaney, one of the victims in the murders of Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner in 1964 Alvin Childress, actor, played the lead role on the Amos 'n' Andy Show Paul Davis, singer-songwriter best known for the late 1970s and early 1980s pop hits "I Go Crazy" and "'65 Love Affair", was born in Meridian in 1948; after retiring, he returned to the city where he remained until his death in 2008 John Fleming, U.S. Representative for Louisiana's 4th congressional district 2009-2017, was born and raised in Meridian Fred and Al Key, known as "The Flying Keys" – holders of the world flight endurance record – are Meridian natives. Al Key is also a former mayor of the city.
gold: Diane Ladd, actress, actually born in Laurel, but raised in Meridian, where her parents resided Hartley Peavey, founder of Peavey Electronics, which is headquartered in Meridian Fred Phelps, former (now deceased) leader of the Westboro Baptist Church David Charles Richardson, commander and vice admiral in the United States Navy Jimmie Rodgers, the "Father of Country Music", was born in the city in 1897. The Jimmie Rodgers Museum is located in Meridian, and the Jimmie Rodgers Festival has been an annual Meridian event since 1953. A winner of 18th season of The Voice. Walker, member of the Louisiana House of Representatives for East Baton Rouge Parish from 1964 to 1972 Charles Young Jr., business executive and current member of the Mississippi House of Representatives Charles L. Young Sr., business executive and former member of the Mississippi House of Representatives In South and West: From a Notebook, Joan Didion recounts that she met a man while visiting Meridian in the 1970s who told her "The KKK which used to be a major factor in this community isn't a factor anymore, both the membership and the influence have diminished, and I cannot think of any place where the black is denied entrance, with the possible exception of private clubs."
text1:
Here is a continuation of the text:
