Throughout the day, it became evident that Andy had organized a set of embarrassing and degrading tasks in an attempt to enhance morale and teamwork. Dwight Schrute was very strict and serious as he assigned tasks and enforced rules during the day's activities. Jim Halpert and Pam Beesly made fun of Andy's actions by exchanging sarcastic remarks and comments all day. Angela Kinsey's character, Angela Martin, displayed her typical disapproval of Andy's perceived lack of ability. Throughout the day, the employees participated in unexpected activities such as karaoke, meditation, and strange icebreaker games. At the end of the event, it was evident that Andy had once again surpassed expectations with his cringeworthy creativity.

prefix: In doing so, they suffered one killed and nine wounded, while the attacking Japanese had suffered heavily, losing 58 men killed. It was the biggest loss since the action at Slater's Knoll and it spelt the end of their attempt to defend the Hongorai.
gold: After this, the Australians were able to resume their advance to the river on 7 May without further opposition. The previous three weeks in which they had advanced to the Hongorai had been costly for them, however, with the Australian 24th Infantry Battalion losing 25 killed and 95 wounded. Against this, the Japanese had lost at least 169 killed. Following the advance to the Hongorai, there was a pause of about a week as the Australians had to wait for roads to be improved and supplies to be brought up, before attempting to cross the Hongorai en masse. This allowed Savige to re-evaluate the situation and to issue new orders for the advance towards the Hari and Mivo Rivers. As they waited for the advance to resume, the Australians carried out reconnaissance patrols deep into Japanese held territory and there were a couple of significant engagements during this time. As a part of these, the 24th Infantry Battalion sent a company across the Hongorai and subsequently located a strong Japanese position on a feature that became known as Egan's Ridge, which, due to its location, commanded the main Australian axis of advance. The main crossing was planned for 20 May, with the 58th/59th Infantry Battalion on the right tasked to cut the Buin Road and the Aitara Track to the east of the river, while on the left the 57th/60th Infantry Battalion would divert the attention of the Japanese off the 24th Infantry Battalion which would make the main frontal assault from the centre of the Australian line, crossing at the Pororei ford, advancing straight up the Buin Road. Preliminary moves began before this, and on 15 May a platoon from the 24th Infantry Battalion along with two tanks attempted to carry out an attack on Egan's Ridge. After one of the tanks was held up and knocked out by a Japanese field gun, they were forced to withdraw. Meanwhile, the RNZAF Corsair squadrons—now reinforced by No. 16 Squadron—began an eight-day aerial campaign, attacking along the length of the Buin and Commando Roads. During this period, the New Zealanders flew 381 sorties, while artillery and mortars fired "thousands of rounds".
text1:
As the news of the defeat spread through the Japanese lines, morale began to sag and discipline started to fray. The once-stalwart defenders of Hongorai began to falter, and soon reports reached Allied headquarters of Japanese soldiers deserting their posts and fleeing into the jungle.

Meanwhile, the Australians took advantage of the reprieve to launch a renewed attack on the Japanese positions. With artillery and air support, they were able to make steady gains, pushing the Japanese back and slowly encircling the remaining strongpoints.

By the end of the day, the Australians had secured a foothold on the northern edge of Hongorai, and the Japanese were forced to withdraw to the southeastern sector of the village. Though they still held out, their resistance was now fragmented and disorganized, and it was clear that their grip on the town was beginning to slip.

As night fell, the Australians consolidated their gains and prepared to launch a final push to clear the remaining Japanese from Hongorai. The battle was far from over, but with their superior numbers and firepower, the Allies were confident of ultimate victory. The end of the Japanese defenses was in sight, and with it, the promise of a long-awaited breakthrough in the relentless campaign for New Guinea.
text2:
The defeated Japanese force withdrew from their defensive positions, leaving behind a tangled web of communication wires, destroyed equipment, and the bodies of their comrades. The Australians, having gained a crucial victory, were tasked with holding the Hongorai River line until reinforcements arrived.

As they settled in for a prolonged defensive campaign, the Australians were keenly aware of the fragile state of their tenuous grip on the region. The Japanese had shown themselves willing and able to adapt their tactics, and would undoubtedly try to regroup and counter-attack. The Australians knew that their hold on the Hongorai River line was a crucial hinge, and that if the Japanese could crack their defensive line, the whole of the region could be lost.

Meanwhile, the Australians were still grappling with the psychological impact of the heavy casualties they had sustained. The loss of one man had sent shockwaves through the ranks, and many were still reeling from the sudden, brutal reality of war. The sounds of gunfire and explosions still echoed in the darkness, a constant reminder that the battle was far from over.
text3: The Japanese soldiers who were defeated retreated from their defensive positions, abandoning communication wires, damaged equipment, and fallen comrades. After securing an important win, the Australians were responsible for maintaining the Hongorai River line until additional troops could join them. The Australians were acutely conscious of the precariousness of their control over the region as they prepared for a long defensive operation. The Japanese soldiers were prepared to adjust their strategies and were likely to attempt a comeback. The Australians understood that losing control of the Hongorai River line would result in the loss of the entire region. The Australians were still struggling with the mental toll of the significant losses they had experienced. The death of a single soldier had a profound impact on the troops, leaving many struggling to come to terms with the harsh realities of war. The ongoing sounds of gunfire and explosions served as a continuous reminder that the battle was ongoing despite the darkness.

prefix: At times, however, the frontier wars did see the involvement of British soldiers and later mounted police units. Not all Aboriginal groups resisted white encroachment on their lands, while many Aborigines served in mounted police units and were involved in attacks on other tribes.
gold: Fighting between Aborigines and Europeans was localised as the Aborigines did not form confederations capable of sustained resistance. As a result, there was not a single war, but rather a series of violent engagements and massacres across the continent. Organised or disorganised however, a pattern of frontier warfare emerged with Aboriginal resistance beginning in the 18th century and continuing into the early 20th century. This warfare contradicts the popular and at times academic "myth" of peaceful settlement in Australia. Faced with Aboriginal resistance settlers often reacted with violence, resulting in a number of indiscriminate massacres. Among the most famous is the Battle of Pinjarra in Western Australia in 1834. Such incidents were not officially sanctioned however, and after the Myall Creek massacre in New South Wales in 1838 seven Europeans were hanged for their part in the killings. However, in Tasmania the so-called Black War was fought between 1828 and 1832, and aimed at driving most of the island's native inhabitants onto a number of isolated peninsulas. Although it began in failure for the British, it ultimately resulted in considerable casualties amongst the native population. It may be inaccurate though to depict the conflict as one sided and mainly perpetrated by Europeans on Aborigines. Although many more Aborigines died than British, this may have had more to do with the technological and logistic advantages enjoyed by the Europeans. Aboriginal tactics varied, but were mainly based on pre-existing hunting and fighting practices—using spears, clubs and other primitive weapons. Unlike the indigenous peoples of New Zealand and North America, on the main Aborigines failed to adapt to meet the challenge of the Europeans. Although there were some instances of individuals and groups acquiring and using firearms, this was not widespread. The Aborigines were never a serious military threat to European settlers, regardless of how much the settlers may have feared them. On occasions large groups of Aborigines attacked the settlers in open terrain and a conventional battle ensued, during which the Aborigines would attempt to use superior numbers to their advantage. This could sometimes be effective, with reports of them advancing in crescent formation in an attempt to outflank and surround their opponents, waiting out the first volley of shots and then hurling their spears while the settlers reloaded. However, such open warfare usually proved more costly for the Aborigines than the Europeans. Central to the success of the Europeans was the use of firearms.
text1:
Despite the involvement of some Aboriginal groups in the colonial forces, many others continued to resist the encroachment of European settlement. In the 1880s, a series of conflicts broke out in Western Australia, known as the Kimberley Wars, as Aboriginal groups, including the Bunuba and Waljeri people, fought against the arrival of white settlers and the construction of a telegraph line. The conflicts were marked by violence and atrocities on both sides, with many Aboriginal people being killed or displaced.

In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the Australian government implemented a range of policies aimed at assimilating Aboriginal people into European culture, including forced removal of children from their families and relocation to missions and reserves. This period, known as the Stolen Generations, saw the forced assimilation of thousands of Aboriginal children, leading to widespread trauma and cultural disruption.

In the second half of the 20th century, there was a growing movement among Aboriginal people and their supporters for recognition of their rights and cultural heritage. In 1967, a referendum was held in which Australian voters were asked to approve changes to the Australian constitution to allow the federal government to make laws for Aboriginal people. The referendum was overwhelmingly supported, and it marked a significant turning point in the struggle for Aboriginal rights.
text2: As the frontier wars raged on, a small but notable number of Aboriginal people began to adapt to the changes brought about by white settlement, often through forced assimilation and conversion to Christianity. Some Aborigines formed alliances with white colonizers, exchanging traditional ways of life for education, Christianity, and material comforts. These Aboriginal converts, often referred to as "assimilationists," were sometimes used by white authorities as interpreters, mediators, and enforcers of British law. They worked to facilitate the spread of European culture and governance, while also attempting to protect their own communities from further marginalization.
text3: During the frontier wars, some Aboriginal people started adjusting to white settlement by assimilating and converting to Christianity. Some Indigenous Australians collaborated with white settlers, trading their traditional customs for education, Christianity, and material possessions. White authorities sometimes utilized Aboriginal converts, known as "assimilationists," as interpreters, mediators, and enforcers of British law. They aimed to promote European culture and government, while also trying to safeguard their communities from additional marginalization.

prefix: A port for Nintendo Switch was released on September 20, 2018 as part of the Sega Ages line of rereleases. It adds features including the ability to use moves from Sonic 2 and Sonic Mania, a challenge mode, a time attack for the first stage, and features from the 3DS rereleases of the game and its sequel.
gold: U.S. Gold acquired the rights to make a version of Sonic the Hedgehog for the Amiga, ZX Spectrum, Commodore 64, Amstrad CPC and Atari ST personal computers, but these went unreleased. Several screenshots exist, some of which resemble the 8-bit version. An enhanced port for the Sega CD was also planned, but was scrapped in favor of Sonic CD. Sonic the Hedgehog was praised by critics, with an 86% rating at the review aggregator GameRankings. It was considered Sega's answer to Nintendo's widely popular Mario series, as it was a platformer featuring the company's mascot. Paul Rand of Computer and Video Games compared the two in depth and characterized Sonic the Hedgehog as being faster, with brighter colors, and Super Mario World as having more "depth of play". Frank Ladoire of believed Sonic the Hedgehog was part of a new generation of games that demonstrate that the Genesis is capable of "beautiful things" in the technical department. Reviewers praised the colorful, detailed graphics. Rand called its color scheme "lively, but never garish", praising the interaction of color with detail in the sprites, backgrounds, and animations and describing its graphics as the best available for the Genesis. Reviewer Boogie Man of GamePro called the intricate backgrounds "eye-popping" and "gorgeous", which was echoed by Mean Machines. The Lessers (Hartley, Patricia, and Kirk) of Dragon claimed the graphics made Sonic a possible contender for the best game of 1991 and GameZone called the animation "some of the smoothest and fastest ... ever seen". Julian Boardman of Raze praised the "colourful and highly detailed" backdrops and "fabulous" sprites. The music and sound effects were also well received; Dragon called them "great", and GameZone "amazing". Rand praised the "catchy" soundtrack, calling some of the sound effects "absolutely brilliant". Although Mean Machines called the songs "vaguely appealing", the sound effects were better appreciated. However, Boardman of Raze considered the music "a little boring". Critics cited the fast gameplay, unprecedented in platformers. The difficulty was disputed, described as "impossible" by Rand and "average" by EGM.
text1:
The Nintendo Switch port of Sonic the Hedgehog received widespread critical acclaim for its faithful recreation of the original game's physics and graphics, as well as the added features that enhanced the overall experience. The inclusion of moves from Sonic 2 and Sonic Mania allowed players to experience a new level of speed and agility, while the challenge mode and time attack added a fresh layer of replayability to the game.

Fans of the series were also pleased to see the return of features from the 3DS rereleases, including the ability to collect chaos emeralds and the special stages that rewarded players with alternate endings. The game's soundtrack, which had been remixed and rearranged for the Switch release, was also praised for its nostalgic value and catchy melodies.

However, not all was perfect with the Switch port. Some players experienced minor issues with the game's physics, citing that they were slightly off from the original game. Additionally, the game's graphics, while visually stunning, were not as sharp as some players had hoped.

Despite these minor drawbacks, the Switch port of Sonic the Hedgehog was a hit among fans and newcomers alike. It marked a triumphant return to form for the blue blur, and proved that even after decades, the game's classic gameplay and charm were still more than enough to captivate audiences.

In the months following its release, the Sega Ages series continued to grow, with more classic Sonic titles receiving the same treatment as the original game. And as the series continued to thrive, it became clear that the Switch port of Sonic the Hedgehog was more than just a re-release - it was a testament to the enduring power of classic gaming and the magic of Sonic the Hedgehog.
text2:
The port also includes a unique feature called "Dream Land", a bonus area that allows players to collect and view concept art, sprites, and music from Sonic the Hedgehog. Players can earn tokens by completing levels or collecting all the chaos emeralds in each zone, which can be used to unlock these hidden items.

Additionally, the port includes a "Sonic Simulator" mode which mimics the feel of playing the original 1991 version on the Mega Drive, including pixel art graphics and authentic sound effects. Fans of the classic game can relive the nostalgia by playing the Sonic the Hedgehog port in its original form, while still benefiting from modern features like save states and online leaderboards.

The port also includes a "Tails Help" feature, where the player can summon Miles "Tails" Prower to assist them in completing levels. This feature is especially useful for beginners or players who struggle with the challenging level design and enemies of the classic game.
text3: The port has a special section called "Dream Land" where players can collect and view concept art, sprites, and music from Sonic the Hedgehog. By finishing levels or finding all the chaos emeralds, players can obtain tokens to unlock the hidden items in "Dream Land." Moreover, the port offers a "Sonic Simulator" mode that replicates the experience of playing the original 1991 version on the Mega Drive, complete with pixel art graphics and genuine sound effects. Players can experience the classic Sonic the Hedgehog game with original features and modern enhancements. Players can use the "Tails Help" feature to call on Miles "Tails" Prower for assistance in finishing levels. This function is particularly beneficial for newcomers or individuals who find the difficult level layout and adversaries of the traditional game challenging.

prefix: The following morning, the British, unable to drag the grounded Acteon off the sandbar, set fire to the ship to prevent her from falling into enemy hands. Patriots in small boats sailed out to the burning ships, and fired some of their cannons at the British ships, took what stores and loot they could, and retreated shortly before the ship's powder magazine exploded.
gold: The British did not attempt to take the fort again. Within days of the battle, Charlestonians learned of the signing of the Declaration of Independence in Philadelphia. The British troops were reembarked on their transports, and on July 21 the British fleet withdrew northward to help the main British army in its campaign against New York City. To add insult to injury, one of the British transports grounded off Long Island and was captured by Patriot forces. The British did not return to Charleston until 1780, when General Clinton successfully besieged the city and captured an entire army. Until the South again became a focus of the war in late 1778, its states provided military supplies to the northern war effort and produced trade goods that brought in valuable hard currency to fund the war effort. Admiral Parker and General Clinton engaged in a war of words after the battle, each seeking to cast the blame on the other for the expedition's failures. Although Clinton was not blamed by the government, popular opinion held him responsible, and Parker was lauded for his personal bravery. Fort Sullivan was renamed Fort Moultrie shortly after the battle to honor Colonel William Moultrie for his successful defense of the fort and the city of Charleston. Extensively modified in the years after the battle, it was supplanted by Fort Sumter as the principal defense of Charleston prior to the outbreak of the American Civil War. In 1876, to celebrate the centennial, companies from Savannah, Augusta, Macon, Columbia, New York and Boston were invited to Charleston. The site was turned over to the National Park Service in 1960, and is now part of Fort Sumter National Monument. A small monument to the Battle of Sullivan's Island has been placed at the northeastern tip of the island, overlooking the inlet where General Clinton's soldiers had hoped to cross. The monument includes historical markers describing the events surrounding the engagement. One iconic emblem of the battle was the flag designed by Colonel Moultrie. Commissioned by the colonial government, he designed a blue flag with a white crescent in the top left corner, which was flown at the fort during the battle. Despite being shot down during the siege, it was seen as a symbol of this successful defense (and famously raised during victory). It came to be known as the Moultrie flag or Liberty Flag.
text1:
As the flames engulfed the Acteon, the British crews on the surrounding ships watched in horror as the ship's masts toppled into the water, sending plumes of sparks flying in all directions. The scent of burning tar and wood filled the air, and the cries of the British sailors could be heard mingling with the crackling of the inferno.

Meanwhile, the Patriots in their small boats, who had been quietly gathering what they could from the stricken ship, found themselves suddenly surrounded by a British ship, its guns blazing. The Patriots quickly retreated, abandoning their loot and making for the safety of the shore. But not before they had tossed a few well-placed grenades at the British vessel, causing it to stumble backwards in surprise.

As the Acteon finally slipped beneath the waves, taking its secrets with it, the British ships began to withdraw from the scene, their mood dark and sullen. The Americans, for their part, celebrated their small victory with a makeshift feast on the beach, feasting on the spoils of war and toasting their bravery.

Little did they know, however, that the burning of the Acteon had not gone unnoticed by the enemy. A small British reconnaissance party, dispatched to survey the damage, had spotted a group of Americans celebrating on the beach. And as the sun began to set on the coast, the British began to prepare for a retaliatory strike, determined to teach the rebels a lesson they would not soon forget.
text2:
As the darkness of the evening fell, the survivors of the British fleet gazed out upon the smoldering remains of the Acteon, a stark reminder of their defeat. The British sailors and Marines had lost 11 men and 45 boats, while the rebels had claimed a crucial victory. The burning ship still sent plumes of smoke high into the evening air, and the flickering flames illuminated the anxious faces of the British officers as they plotted their next move.

Meanwhile, in the midst of the chaos, a small group of rebels had commandeered one of the British boats and were rapidly rowing towards the nearby shore. They knew the British would soon regroup and prepare a counter-attack, and they aimed to strike first. The party, led by a grizzled old patriot named Captain John Parker, consisted of some of the fiercest fighters in the rebellion. They knew the British were gathering strength, and they sought to strike a crippling blow before they could muster their forces.

As the rebels disembarked onto the beach, Captain Parker turned to his men and growled, "We've got to act fast! The British are regrouping, and we don't know how long we'll be able to keep them off our backs." He surveyed the landscape, his eyes settling on the nearby fort, which was still held by a small contingent of British soldiers. "That's our target. We've got to take that fort, and we've got to take it before sunrise!"

The men nodded assent, their faces set in determination. They knew the risk they took, but they also knew the potential reward. With the fort in rebel hands, the British would be severely hampered in their efforts to re-establish control over the city. The stage was set for a desperate, high-stakes battle that would decide the fate of the rebellion.
text3: At nightfall, the British fleet survivors looked at the burning Acteon, a clear symbol of their loss. The rebels achieved a significant win, resulting in the loss of 11 men and 45 boats for the British sailors and Marines. The British officers anxiously planned their next move as the burning ship continued to emit smoke and flickering flames. Amidst the turmoil, a few rebels took control of a British boat and were quickly rowing towards the shore. They were aware that the British would regroup and plan a counter-attack, so they wanted to be the first to strike. Captain John Parker led a group of fierce rebel fighters in the party. They were aware of the British regrouping and wanted to launch a decisive attack before the enemy could gather their forces. Captain Parker urged his men to move quickly as they landed on the beach. The British are regrouping, and we are uncertain about how long we can delay their counter-attack. He looked around and focused on the fort nearby, where a few British soldiers were still stationed. "That is what we need to focus on." We need to capture the fort before the sun comes up! The men agreed with determined expressions on their faces. They were aware of the danger involved, but they also understood the possible benefits. If the rebels capture the fort, it will make it difficult for the British to regain control of the city. A crucial battle was imminent, with the outcome determining the rebellion's future.

prefix: When the original roadways between Ironwood and Iron River were completed in late 1915, the Upper Peninsula Development Bureau (UPDB) named the area Cloverland and the highway the Cloverland Trail. Later the name was extended over the highway to Escanaba, and to all highways in the area in the early 1920s; the name was phased out by the UPDB completely in 1927.
gold: The roadways were also used for the Theodore Roosevelt International Highway, named for former US president Theodore Roosevelt after his death in 1919. Overall, this highway ran from Portland, Oregon, to Portland, Maine, by way of Michigan and the Canadian province of Ontario. Through the UP, the southern branch followed the immediate predecessors to US 2, including the section through Florence County, Wisconsin. The Great Lakes Automobile Route was established in 1917 by the UPDB. A predecessor of the Great Lakes Circle Tours by seventy years, the route followed "a circular journey along the banks of lakes Michigan and Superior and Green Bay ..." This route followed the modern US 2 from Ironwood to the M‑94 junction in Manistique, using the modern M‑69 and M‑95 to stay in Michigan. Branches of the route followed US 41 and M‑35 between Powers and Escanaba. The route was originally intended to entice motorists to drive around Lake Michigan. The name fell out of use before its first anniversary because of World War I. One Canadian auto trail was routed through the UP as well. In 1920, the King's International Highway linked Vancouver, British Columbia, to Halifax, Nova Scotia, but there was no highway to carry it around the north side of Lake Superior. Motorists had to ship their cars by boat between Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, and Thunder Bay or enter the United States to continue along the auto trail. The routings varied on the maps of the time, but its basic route used US 2 through the UP from Ironwood to Sault Ste. Marie until a highway north of Lake Superior was opened in 1960; by that time, the auto trail had taken on the Trans-Canada Highway name. The first state trunkline highway designated along the path of the modern US 2 was M‑12, a designation that was in use by July 1, 1919, between Ironwood and Sault Ste. Marie. The first roadside park in the country was created by Herbert Larson near what is now US 2 near Iron River in 1919–20. When the US Highway System was created on November 11, 1926, US 2 partially replaced M-12. Between Crystal Falls and Iron Mountain, US 2 was routed through Florence, Wisconsin. The former routing of M‑12 from Crystal Falls to Sagola became a new M‑69 when the former M‑69 became US 102 (now US 141).
text1:
Despite the name "Cloverland" being phased out by the UPDB, the region continued to thrive and grow. The highway that once bore the name became a vital link between Ironwood and Escanaba, connecting the towns and cities of the Upper Peninsula. As the years passed, the highway underwent several improvements, including the construction of new bridges and the widening of lanes.

In the 1950s, the highway was officially designated as part of the state's main highway system, and was given the number US-2. The designation helped to solidify the highway's importance in the region, and it continued to play a crucial role in the transportation of goods and people.

Today, the highway remains a vital artery in the Upper Peninsula, connecting the cities and towns of the region to the rest of the state and the country. While the name "Cloverland" may be a relic of the past, the highway that once bore that name continues to serve as a vital link between the people and communities of the Upper Peninsula.
text2:
Despite the eventual phase-out of the name Cloverland, the region continued to grow and prosper, with the highways remaining a vital connection point for residents and businesses in the Upper Peninsula. The highway became known as M-38, and remains an important transportation artery to this day.

In the decades that followed, the area underwent significant changes, with the growth of industries such as mining, logging, and manufacturing drawing in new settlers and investment. The towns and villages along M-38, including Ironwood, Iron River, and Escanaba, developed their own unique cultures and characteristics, with a strong sense of community and a deep connection to the region's natural beauty and rich natural resources.

Today, M-38 is a scenic highway that winds its way through the Upper Peninsula's stunning natural landscape, offering motorists a glimpse into the region's history and culture. The highway is lined with historic landmarks, quaint small towns and villages, and abundant outdoor recreational opportunities, making it a popular destination for travelers and locals alike. Despite the passage of time, the Cloverland Trail may be gone, but its legacy lives on in the form of the thriving community and natural beauty that it connected to so many years ago.
text3: Even after Cloverland was phased out, the region thrived and the highways remained crucial for residents and businesses in the Upper Peninsula. M-38, the highway that replaced Cloverland, continues to be a vital transportation route. Over time, the region experienced major transformations as industries like mining, logging, and manufacturing attracted new residents and investments. Communities along M-38, such as Ironwood, Iron River, and Escanaba, cultivated distinct identities rooted in community spirit and appreciation for the area's natural resources. M-38 now meanders through the picturesque natural scenery of the Upper Peninsula, providing drivers with a view of the region's rich history and culture. M-38 is a sought-after destination for both tourists and locals due to its historic sites, charming towns, and outdoor activities. Although the Cloverland Trail may no longer exist, its impact can still be seen in the flourishing community and beautiful landscapes it once linked together.

prefix: Parker's fleet had an extremely difficult crossing. Battered by storms and high seas, the first ships of the fleet did not arrive at Cape Fear until April 18, and Cornwallis did not arrive until May 3.
gold: After several weeks there, in which the British troops raided Patriot properties, Clinton, Cornwallis and Parker concluded that Cape Fear was not a suitable base for further operations. Parker had sent out some ships on scouting expeditions up and down the coast, and reports on the partially finished condition of the Charleston defenses were sufficiently promising that the decision was made to go there. John Rutledge, recently elected president of the General Assembly that remained as the backbone of South Carolina's revolutionary government, organized a defense force under the command of 46-year-old Colonel William Moultrie, a former militiaman and Indian fighter. These forces comprised three infantry regiments, two rifle regiments, and a small artillery regiment; they were augmented by three independent artillery companies, and the total force numbered about 2,000. These forces were further augmented by the arrival of Continental regiments from North Carolina and Virginia (1,900 troops), as well as militia numbering 2,700 from Charleston and the surrounding backcountry. Moultrie saw Sullivan's Island, a sandy spit of land at the entrance to Charleston Harbor extending north about long and a few hundred yards wide, as a place well suited to build a fort that could protect the entrance from intruding enemy warships. A large vessel sailing into Charleston first had to cross Charleston Bar, a series of submerged shoals lying about southeast of the city, and then pass by the southern end of Sullivan's Island as it entered the channel to the inner harbor. Later it would also have to pass the northern end of James Island, where Fort Johnson commanded the southeastern approach to the city. Moultrie and his 2nd South Carolina Regiment arrived on Sullivan's Island in March 1776, and began construction of a fortress built out of palmetto logs to defend the island and the channel into Charleston Harbor. The construction moved slowly; Captain Peter Horry of the Patriot naval detachment described the site as "an immense pen 500 feet long, and 16 feet wide, filled with sand to stop the shot". The gun platforms were made of planks two inches thick and fastened with wooden spikes. Congress had appointed General Lee to command the Continental Army troops in the southern colonies, and his movements by land shadowed those of Clinton's fleet as it sailed south. Lee wrote from Wilmington on June 1 that the fleet had sailed, but that he did not know whether it was sailing for Virginia or South Carolina. He headed for Charleston, saying "[I] confess I know not whether I shall go to or from the enemy."
text1:
Despite the grueling journey, Cornwallis was relieved to finally set foot on American soil, but his relief was short-lived. As he began to establish a camp at Wilmington, he was met with news that the French fleet, led by Admiral François Joseph Paul de Grasse, had arrived in the Chesapeake Bay, threatening to cut off his supply lines to Charleston. Cornwallis knew he had to act quickly to secure his position and prevent a potential disaster.

He dispatched a portion of his troops to fortify the port city of Wilmington, while also sending out reconnaissance parties to gather intelligence on the French fleet's movements. Meanwhile, his naval commander, Admiral Pierre-André de Suffren, set sail to engage the French and disrupt their supply lines. The fate of the British campaign in the Carolinas hung in the balance, as Cornwallis and his troops prepared for a long and arduous fight to maintain their grip on the region.
text2:
As the battered fleet finally reached the shores of Cape Fear, the weary soldiers and sailors of Parker's fleet were greeted by a chill spring breeze and a landscape ravaged by war. The village of Wilmington was in shambles, its buildings battered and abandoned by the British occupation. The remnants of the civilian population, already worn down by years of conflict, gazed out at the exhausted sailors with a mix of curiosity and suspicion.

Parker, shaken but relieved, quickly set about assessing the damages to the ships and tending to the wounded. The stormy seas had claimed several vessels, and many more were badly damaged, with leaks and broken masts threatening to send the remaining ships to the bottom. As the sailors set about repairing their battered craft, Cornwallis, who had arrived earlier that month, looked on with a mixture of concern and disdain.

"Why did it take you so long, General Parker?" he asked, his tone icy as the spring air. "We were supposed to be here weeks ago, and now we are already falling behind schedule."

Parker, tired and frustrated, shot back, "You know as well as I, General, that the sea has its own whims, and we are at its mercy. We did our best, and we arrived as quickly as was possible given the circumstances."

Cornwallis snorted, dismissing the excuse with a wave of his hand. "Enough, General Parker. We have no time for excuses. We must press on with the campaign, and that requires getting our troops and supplies moved to the interior of the colony as quickly as possible."

Parker nodded stiffly, knowing that Cornwallis was right. The fate of the British campaign in the Carolinas hung in the balance, and every day counted. As the two generals conferred on the next steps to take, the weary soldiers of Parker's fleet gazed out at the shattered remnants of Wilmington, wondering what lay ahead on the long and bloody path that was to come.
text3: Upon arriving at Cape Fear, the exhausted soldiers and sailors of Parker's fleet were met with a cold spring wind and a war-torn landscape. Wilmington was left in ruins, with its structures damaged and deserted due to the British presence. The tired sailors were met with a mix of curiosity and suspicion from the war-weary civilians. Parker wasted no time in checking the ships for damage and caring for the injured. Numerous ships were lost at sea during the storm, while others suffered significant damage that put them at risk of sinking. Cornwallis observed with a mix of worry and contempt as the sailors worked on fixing their damaged ships. General Parker, why did you delay your arrival? He inquired with a cold demeanor matching the chilly spring weather. "We were meant to arrive weeks earlier, and now we're already lagging behind." Parker responded, attributing the delay to the unpredictable nature of the sea. We made every effort to arrive promptly considering the situation. Cornwallis scoffed and disregarded the excuse with a gesture. "General Parker, that's sufficient." There is no room for justifications. It is imperative that we continue the campaign by swiftly relocating our troops and supplies to the colony's interior. Parker acknowledged Cornwallis' correctness with a stiff nod. The outcome of the British campaign in the Carolinas was uncertain, and time was of the essence. During their discussion, the exhausted soldiers of Parker's fleet looked out at the destroyed Wilmington, pondering the challenges that awaited them on the difficult journey ahead.

prefix: was a pre-dreadnought battleship built for the Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN) in the late 1890s. As Japan lacked the industrial capacity to build such warships itself, the ship was designed and built in the United Kingdom.
gold: Shortly after her arrival in Japan, she became flagship of the Standing Fleet, the IJN's primary combat fleet. She participated in every major naval battle of the Russo-Japanese War of 1904–1905 and was lightly damaged during the Battle of the Yellow Sea and the Battle of Tsushima. Asahi saw no combat during World War I, although the ship participated in the Siberian Intervention in 1918. Reclassified as a coastal defence ship in 1921, Asahi was disarmed two years later to meet the terms of the Washington Naval Treaty, after which she served as a training and submarine depot ship.
text1:
The design and construction of the pre-dreadnought battleship was a collaborative effort between the British shipbuilding company, Armstrong Whitworth, and the Imperial Japanese Navy. The ship, which was named "Hatsuse", was laid down at the Armstrong Whitworth yard in Elswick, Newcastle upon Tyne, in 1896 and was launched in 1897. After a series of sea trials and modifications, the Hatsuse was finally commissioned into the IJN in August 1899.

The Hatsuse was a significant improvement over Japan's existing warships, with a displacement of over 9,000 tons and a main armament of four 12-inch guns. Its speed was also impressive, reaching over 18 knots (33 km/h) thanks to a combination of triple-expansion steam engines and a propeller. The ship's design was influenced by the British Royal Navy's experience with battleships, and it featured a central gun turret and a high bridge deck.

After its commissioning, the Hatsuse played a key role in the IJN's naval buildup and modernization efforts. It participated in several fleet exercises and was used as a training ship for the Japanese navy's officers. The Hatsuse also served as the flagship of the Japanese fleet during the Russo-Japanese War, and it played a minor role in the Battle of Tsushima in 1905.

Despite its impressive performance, the Hatsuse had a relatively short service life. It was decommissioned in 1919 and subsequently scrapped in the early 1920s. However, its legacy lived on, and it played a significant role in the development of the Japanese navy's modernization and expansion efforts during the early 20th century.
text2:
The pre-dreadnought battleship, named "Kasuga", was built by the British company Armstrong Whitworth at Elswick, Newcastle upon Tyne. The ship was launched on November 16, 1897, and was fitted out and completed at the Royal Dockyard at Chatham, Kent. The Kasuga was a testament to the close relations between the Japanese and British navies, with many Japanese naval officers receiving training in Britain and British officers advising on the construction of Japanese warships.

Upon its completion, the Kasuga was one of the largest and most advanced warships in the world, with a displacement of over 11,000 tons and a crew of over 700 men. The ship was heavily armed, with a main battery of four 12-inch guns and a secondary battery of eight 6-inch guns, making it one of the most powerful warships in the Far Eastern theatre.

Following its arrival in Japan in 1899, the Kasuga was initially based at Yokohama, serving as the flagship of the Japanese Third Fleet. The ship played a key role in the Japanese naval build-up in the late 1890s, serving as the primary training vessel for the Japanese naval academy and as a flagship for exercises and fleet deployments. Throughout the early 1900s, the Kasuga continued to play a key role in the Japanese Navy, serving as the centerpiece of the Japanese naval fleet until its retirement in the mid-1910s.
text3: Armstrong Whitworth built the pre-dreadnought battleship "Kasuga" in Newcastle upon Tyne. The vessel was launched in 1897 and finished at the Royal Dockyard in Chatham, Kent. The Kasuga symbolized the strong ties between the Japanese and British navies, with Japanese officers trained in Britain and British officers assisting in the construction of Japanese warships. After being finished, the Kasuga was considered one of the most advanced and largest warships globally, boasting a displacement exceeding 11,000 tons and a crew of more than 700 sailors. Equipped with four 12-inch guns and eight 6-inch guns, the Kasuga was among the most formidable warships in the Far East. Upon reaching Japan in 1899, the Kasuga was stationed in Yokohama and operated as the main ship of the Japanese Third Fleet. The vessel was crucial in the expansion of the Japanese navy in the late 1890s, acting as the main training ship for the Japanese naval academy and leading exercises and fleet missions. The Kasuga remained a central figure in the Japanese Navy during the early 1900s, leading the naval fleet until its retirement in the mid-1910s.

prefix: The ship was powered by two vertical triple-expansion steam engines built by Humphrys, Tennant, each driving one propeller, using steam generated by 25 Belleville boilers at a working pressure of . The engines were rated at , using forced draught, and designed to reach a top speed of although Asahi reached from during her sea trials on 23 March 1900.
gold: She carried a maximum of of coal which allowed her to steam for at a speed of . The ship was fitted with three steam-driven dynamos. Asahis main battery consisted of the same four Elswick Ordnance Company 40-calibre twelve-inch guns used in all of Japan's preceding battleships. They were mounted in twin-gun turrets fore and aft of the superstructure. The hydraulically powered mountings allowed the guns to be loaded at all angles of traverse, at a fixed elevation of +13.5°. Each mount could traverse a total of 240 degrees. They fired projectiles at a muzzle velocity of . The ship's secondary armament consisted of fourteen 40-calibre quick-firing (QF) guns mounted in casemates. Eight of these guns were positioned on the main deck and the other six guns were placed above them in the superstructure. They fired shells at a muzzle velocity of . Protection against torpedo-boat attacks was provided by twenty QF 12-pounder 12 cwt guns. The 12-pounders fired , projectiles at a muzzle velocity of . Lighter guns consisted of eight three-pounder Hotchkiss guns and four 47-millimetre 2.5-pounder Hotchkiss guns. The former were mounted in the superstructure and the latter in the fighting tops. The three-pounder gun fired projectiles at a muzzle velocity of , while the 2.5-pounder fired shells at a muzzle velocity of . The ship was also equipped with four submerged 18-inch torpedo tubes, two on each broadside. The waterline main belt of Asahi consisted of Harvey armour high, of which was above the waterline at normal load, and had a maximum thickness of for the middle of the ship. It was only thick at the ends of the ship and was surmounted by a six-inch strake of armour that ran between the barbettes. The barbettes were thick, but only behind the upper armour strake. The barbette hoods were protected by 10 inches of armour on their face while their sides were 6 inches thick and the roof was thick. Diagonal bulkheads connecting the barbettes to the side armour were 12–14 inches thick, but only 6 inches thick at the lower deck level.
text1:
After a successful maiden voyage, Asahi began her service as a passenger liner, sailing between Japan and the United States. The ship's luxurious accommodations and advanced steam engines made it a popular choice among passengers, who appreciated the comfort and speed she offered. In her early years, Asahi was also used for cargo transportation, carrying goods such as silk, tea, and machinery between the two countries.

As the years went by, Asahi underwent several modifications to keep her competitive in the ever-evolving shipping industry. In 1906, the ship's boilers were upgraded to burn oil instead of coal, increasing her efficiency and reducing her operating costs. The ship's propellers were also replaced with more efficient designs, allowing her to maintain her top speed of despite the added weight of the oil-fired boilers.

In the 1920s, Asahi was converted into a troopship, serving during World War I as a transport vessel for Japanese soldiers. After the war, the ship was used for a variety of purposes, including passenger transportation, cargo carrying, and even as a temporary hospital ship during times of crisis.

Despite her long and varied service life, Asahi's engines remained reliable and powerful, earning her the nickname "The Workhorse of the Pacific" among sailors and shipbuilders. Eventually, after nearly three decades of service, Asahi was retired from active duty and laid up in a Japanese shipyard, where she remained until her eventual scrapping in the 1950s.
text2:
The successful sea trials of Asahi were followed by a series of rigorous tests to ensure the reliability and performance of the ship's systems and engines. Over the next several weeks, the crew conducted a thorough examination of the ship's propulsion, steering, and maneuverability, making adjustments as necessary. The ship's top speed of over 19 knots, or 22 miles per hour, impressed the naval officers conducting the trials, and was a testament to the skilled engineering and design that had gone into the construction of Asahi.

Following the successful trials, the Japanese Imperial Navy took delivery of Asahi on April 15, 1900, and she was formally commissioned as the lead ship of the Japanese Third Cruiser Division. Asahi played a key role in the Japanese naval fleet, serving as a flagship for Admiral Miura Saneatsu during a number of high-profile exercises and maneuvers. She also played a key part in the Japanese-Russian War, serving as part of the Japanese naval forces that engaged and defeated the Russian Pacific Fleet at the Battle of Tsushima in May 1905.

Throughout her long and storied career, Asahi proved herself to be a reliable, powerful, and maneuverable warship, earning the respect and admiration of her crew and her contemporaries. She remained in active service with the Japanese Imperial Navy until 1945, and was eventually retired and scrapped. Despite her eventual fate, the legacy of Asahi as one of the pioneering warships of the late 19th and early 20th centuries continues to be remembered and celebrated in naval circles.
text3: After Asahi's successful sea trials, a series of thorough tests were conducted to confirm the ship's systems and engines were reliable and performed well. In the following weeks, the crew carefully inspected the ship's propulsion, steering, and maneuvering capabilities, making any needed adjustments. The naval officers conducting the trials were impressed by Asahi's top speed of over 19 knots, which demonstrated the skilled engineering and design behind the ship's construction. Asahi was officially handed over to the Japanese Imperial Navy on April 15, 1900, and became the flagship of the Japanese Third Cruiser Division. Asahi served as the flagship for Admiral Miura Saneatsu during various important naval exercises and maneuvers in the Japanese fleet. She was instrumental in the Japanese-Russian War, participating in the Battle of Tsushima where the Japanese naval forces defeated the Russian Pacific Fleet in May 1905. Asahi's extensive service history showcased her as a dependable, formidable, and agile vessel, earning the admiration of both her crew and peers. She served with the Japanese Imperial Navy until 1945, when she was retired and dismantled. Asahi's reputation as a groundbreaking warship of the late 19th and early 20th centuries lives on in naval history.

prefix: Route 29 is a state highway in the U.S. state of New Jersey. It runs from an interchange with Interstate 295 (I-295) in Hamilton Township in Mercer County, where it continues as I-195, to Route 12 (Bridge Street / Race Street) in Frenchtown, Hunterdon County.
gold: Between the southern terminus and I-295 in Ewing Township, the route is a mix of freeway and four-lane divided highway that runs along the Delaware River through Trenton. This section includes a truck-restricted tunnel that was built along the river near historic houses and Riverview Cemetery. North of I-295, Route 29 turns into a scenic and mostly two-lane highway. North of the South Trenton Tunnel, it is designated the Delaware River Scenic Byway, a New Jersey Scenic Byway and National Scenic Byway, that follows the Delaware River in mostly rural sections of Mercer County and Hunterdon County. The obsolete Delaware & Raritan Canal usually stands between the river and the highway. Most sections of this portion of Route 29 are completely shaded due to the tree canopy. Route 29 also has a spur, Route 129, which connects Route 29 to U.S. Route 1 (US 1) in Trenton. Route 29 was initially designated in 1927 to run from downtown Trenton to Newark, following present-day Route 179 and US 202 between Lambertville and Somerville and US 22 between Somerville and Newark. The route between Lambertville and Frenchtown was originally Route 29A.
text1:
From Frenchtown, Route 29 continues northward along the west bank of the Delaware River, passing through the historic towns of Lambertville and Delaware Township. The route forms the main street of both towns, with a mix of shops, restaurants, and antique stores lining the road. As it approaches the Pennsylvania border, Route 29 intersects with U.S. Route 202 and briefly becomes a four-lane highway before narrowing back down to a two-lane road.

In Pennsylvania, Route 29 crosses the Delaware River on the Delaware River-Frankford Bridge, which offers stunning views of the Delaware River and the New Jersey Palisades. The route continues on the other side of the river, passing through the town of Milford and eventually terminating at an intersection with U.S. Route 6 in the village of Portland. Throughout its length, Route 29 provides scenic views of the Delaware River and the surrounding countryside, making it a popular route for both locals and tourists.
text2:
The highway passes through a mix of urban, suburban, and rural landscapes, providing access to several major communities, including Hamilton Township, Lawrenceville, and Stockton. Along its route, Route 29 intersects with several significant regional roads, including Routes 33, 156, and 179.

Throughout its length, Route 29 is a four-lane highway with a posted speed limit of 55-65 miles per hour, with several traffic signals and interchanges allowing for safe and efficient travel. The road is maintained by the New Jersey Department of Transportation and is an important corridor for both local and regional traffic.

In the town of Stockton, Route 29 passes through the historic downtown area and features several notable points of interest, including the Stockton Historic District, the Stockton Battlefield State Park, and the St. Andrew's Cemetery. Further south, the road continues through the scenic countryside of western Hunterdon County, where it intersects with Route 12 in Frenchtown, providing access to the Delaware River and the town's historic downtown area.
text3: The highway goes through various types of landscapes and connects to several major communities such as Hamilton Township, Lawrenceville, and Stockton. Route 29 intersects with important regional roads like Routes 33, 156, and 179 as it travels. Route 29 is a four-lane highway with a speed limit of 55-65 miles per hour, featuring traffic signals and interchanges for safe and efficient travel. The New Jersey Department of Transportation oversees the maintenance of Route 29, which serves as a crucial route for both local and regional traffic. Route 29 travels through Stockton's historic downtown area, showcasing attractions like the Stockton Historic District, Stockton Battlefield State Park, and St. Andrew's Cemetery. Continuing south, the highway passes through the picturesque rural areas of western Hunterdon County, meeting Route 12 in Frenchtown and granting entry to the Delaware River and the town's historic downtown.

prefix: The road continues along the Lake Michigan shoreline, passing Mystery Spot near Gros Cap and turning inland immediately west of St. Ignace. The US 2 designation ends at the highway's partial cloverleaf interchange with I‑75.
gold: The roadway continues easterly into downtown St. Ignace as Business Loop I‑75 (BL I‑75). In 1701, the first transportation routes through what became the state of Michigan were the lakes, rivers and Indian trails. Two of these trails followed parts of the future US 2. The Sault–Green Bay Trail roughly followed the Lake Michigan shoreline routing of US 2 between Escanaba and St. Ignace. The Mackinac Trail connected St. Ignace with Sault Ste. Marie. In the age of the auto trail, the roads that later formed US 2 through the UP were given a few different highway names. When the original roadways between Ironwood and Iron River were completed in late 1915, the Upper Peninsula Development Bureau (UPDB) named the area Cloverland and the highway the Cloverland Trail. Later the name was extended over the highway to Escanaba, and to all highways in the area in the early 1920s; the name was phased out by the UPDB completely in 1927. The roadways were also used for the Theodore Roosevelt International Highway, named for former US president Theodore Roosevelt after his death in 1919. Overall, this highway ran from Portland, Oregon, to Portland, Maine, by way of Michigan and the Canadian province of Ontario. Through the UP, the southern branch followed the immediate predecessors to US 2, including the section through Florence County, Wisconsin. The Great Lakes Automobile Route was established in 1917 by the UPDB. A predecessor of the Great Lakes Circle Tours by seventy years, the route followed "a circular journey along the banks of lakes Michigan and Superior and Green Bay ..." This route followed the modern US 2 from Ironwood to the M‑94 junction in Manistique, using the modern M‑69 and M‑95 to stay in Michigan. Branches of the route followed US 41 and M‑35 between Powers and Escanaba. The route was originally intended to entice motorists to drive around Lake Michigan. The name fell out of use before its first anniversary because of World War I. One Canadian auto trail was routed through the UP as well. In 1920, the King's International Highway linked Vancouver, British Columbia, to Halifax, Nova Scotia, but there was no highway to carry it around the north side of Lake Superior. Motorists had to ship their cars by boat between Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, and Thunder Bay or enter the United States to continue along the auto trail. The routings varied on the maps of the time, but its basic route used US 2 through the UP from Ironwood to Sault Ste.
text1:
From the interchange with I-75, US 2 turns northward, continuing its journey through the Upper Peninsula. The highway passes through a mix of dense forests and rolling hills, providing scenic views of the surrounding countryside. As it approaches the town of Newberry, US 2 intersects with M-123, a route that takes travelers to the scenic Lake Superior shoreline.

After passing through Newberry, US 2 enters the Hiawatha National Forest, where it winds its way through rugged terrain and scenic valleys. The highway continues northward, eventually reaching the town of Rudyard, where it intersects with M-28. This intersection marks the start of a more rural stretch of US 2, with the highway passing through quiet towns and villages along the way.

As US 2 approaches the Canada-US border, it begins to climb in elevation, passing through the scenic Porcupine Mountains. The highway crosses into Ontario, Canada, where it becomes Highway 17 East. From here, travelers can continue northward to the Soo Locks in Sault Ste. Marie, or turn westward to explore the many attractions of Lake Superior's North Shore.
text2: As the road transitions away from the lakeshore, it merges with US 23, forming a concurrency with the business route of I-75. The highway traverses the industrial and commercial areas of St. Ignace, providing access to the town's downtown shops and restaurants. The road continues northwest, crossing under I-75 and entering a more rural terrain. The speed limit decreases as the road winds through the scenic countryside, passing by farmland and wooded areas. After approximately 10 miles, the US 23 business route ends at a traffic light, where the road continues as M-129. The highway now follows the southern shoreline of the St. Clair River, providing scenic views of the river and the Canadian coast.
text3: The road merges with US 23 as it moves away from the lakeshore, creating a concurrency with the business route of I-75. The road goes through St. Ignace's industrial and commercial districts, allowing drivers to reach the town's downtown businesses and eateries. The road heads northwest, passing under I-75 and transitioning into a more rural landscape. The road slows down as it meanders through the picturesque rural areas, going past farms and forests. The US 23 business route transitions into M-129 after about 10 miles at a traffic light. The highway runs along the south side of the St. Clair River, offering picturesque views of the river and the Canadian shore.

prefix: Richmond grew up in Ashland, Ohio. His parents, Al and Evelyn (née Warner) Richmond, met in the course of their work.
gold: Al was a welder for pipe construction companies and Evelyn was a field office manager. Noticing that highway crews had to dig up the entire highway to lay pipe, Al designed a machine to bore underneath the highway. To market this invention, he founded Richmond Manufacturing, which eventually exported machines worldwide. Tim's driving days started as a toddler when he was given a go-kart that he often drove inside buildings and across his lawn. He later raced the kart at tracks in Moreland and New Pittsburg. Richmond grew up in a well-to-do family, and was sometimes therefore treated differently by his classmates, so his parents enrolled him in Miami Military Academy in Miami, Florida. During his years in Miami, Tim and his mother moved to Florida and his father stayed in Ohio. While home in Ohio over a summer break, he met local drag racer Raymond Beadle through lifelong friend Fred Miller. When Richmond reached age 16, his parents purchased him a Pontiac Trans Am, a speedboat and a Piper Cherokee airplane for his birthday. Yet his mother Evelyn often worried about spoiling her only son. She once said, "Tim was lazy...", and "... I did everything for him. I ruined him, I admit it. He was my whole life." Richmond excelled in sports; he set a conference record in high hurdles and his high school football career was stellar enough that the academy retired his sports jersey after his gridiron days were over. Miami Military Academy named him Athlete of the Year in 1970. Richmond's other interests included flying, and he earned his private pilot license at age 16. Following high school graduation, Richmond attended Ashland University for about one year before dropping out. A friend of Richmond's father co-owned a sprint car and Richmond joined the team as a crew member for Dave Shoemaker. In 1976, 21-year-old Richmond took the car onto Lakeville Speedway at Lakeville, Ohio for some practice laps. "Somebody put a stopwatch on me," Richmond said. "I was running laps faster than Dave had been. It was the first time I had ever driven a race car." Richmond and his father found a red, white and blue-colored No. 98 car in Pennsylvania, which was the same number and paint scheme that Richmond used on model cars as a child. In his first competition at the track, officials placed Richmond in the slowest heat. He passed several cars before spinning out and breaking an axle.
text1: As a child, Richmond was fascinated by his parents' stories about their jobs, which sparked his curiosity about the world beyond Ashland. His mother, Evelyn, was a librarian, and Richmond would often accompany her on visits to the local elementary schools, where she would read to the students. His father, Al, worked as a landscape designer, and Richmond would join him on weekends to help with gardening and yard work. These experiences instilled in Richmond a love for literature and the natural world, which would shape his creative pursuits as he grew older.
text2: As a result, Al, a machinist, and Evelyn, a high school English teacher, instilled in their son an appreciation for the arts and a strong work ethic. Richmond's early life was spent exploring the scenic Hocking River and surrounding countryside, where he developed a passion for storytelling and a keen sense of observation. His parents encouraged his creativity, supporting his early attempts at writing and music-making, even recording his first compositions on a homemade tape deck in the family's attic.
text3: Al, a machinist, and Evelyn, a high school English teacher, taught their son to value the arts and hard work. Richmond grew up in the countryside near the Hocking River, where he honed his storytelling skills and observational abilities. His creativity was nurtured by his parents, who backed his early writing and music endeavors, going as far as recording his initial compositions on a makeshift tape deck in the attic.

prefix: Both road and rail travel through the community of Quinnesec, where they pass near the largest paper mill in the UP. The trunkline runs along the main street of Norway, where the highway meets the eastern terminus of US 8.
gold: Then US 2 continues east through rural Dickinson County to Vulcan, passing north of Hanbury Lake through the Copper Country State Forest, before crossing the Sturgeon River in Loretto and passing into Menominee County. In Menominee County, the environment takes on a more agricultural character along US 2. The highway passes through the edge of the community of Hermansville before entering Powers. US 2 comes to a three-way intersection and turns northeast merging onto US 41. The concurrent highway runs from Powers through the communities of Wilson and Spaulding on the south side of the CN Railway. At Harris, the trunkline enters the Hannahville Indian Community. Harris is on the Menominee County side of the reservation, but as the highway continues east, it crosses over to Bark River on the Delta County side. The county line in between not only separates the two communities, but also serves as the boundary between the Central and Eastern time zones. East of Bark River, the highway crosses the community's namesake waterway before intersecting the eastern terminus of M‑69. The roadway crosses the Ford River prior to turning due east into the outskirts of Escanaba. US 2/US 41 widens to four lanes along Ludington Street, which forms the east–west axis of the Escanaba street grid. Near downtown, the highway meets M‑35, which runs along the city's north–south axis, Lincoln Road. The trunklines merge and run north, bypassing the traditional central business district for a different business corridor. Lincoln Road runs north carrying four lanes of traffic past the Upper Peninsula State Fairgrounds, site of one of the two state fairs for the state of Michigan, the only state to have twin fairs. US 2/US 41/M‑35 continues north on Lincoln Road past the campus of Bay de Noc Community College. The four-lane highway crosses the Escanaba River just upstream from its mouth near the large Verso Esky Paper Mill and shifts to run immediately next to Little Bay de Noc. The section here carried the highest traffic counts along all of US 2 in the state: an average of 23,977 vehicles used this segment of roadway daily in 2011. The road turns inland again, and US 2/US 41/M‑35 passes to the west of downtown Gladstone. The highway through here is an expressway, four lanes divided by a central median and no driveway access. Unlike a freeway, the expressway has standard intersections and not interchanges.
text1: From Norway, the highway continues northward, passing through the charming towns of Iron Mountain and Florence, before arriving at the Upper Peninsula's largest city, Escanaba. Here, travelers can enjoy a variety of amenities, including restaurants, shops, and cultural attractions like the Escanaba Public Library and the Upper Peninsula Children's Museum. The highway then turns west, following the scenic Escanaba River and the Lake Michigan shoreline, before reaching the quaint fishing village of Gladstone. As it winds its way through the countryside, the highway passes through picturesque towns like Rapid River and Gladstone, offering stunning views of the surrounding wilderness and Lake Michigan's picturesque shoreline.
text2: As the road and rail travel converge, the scenic views of the nearby Little Twin Lakes and the majestic Norway Mountain provide a picturesque backdrop to the bustling industrial area. Just north of Norway, the US 45 freeway intersects with US 45 Alternate, forming a Y-intersection that funnels northbound traffic toward Ishpeming and beyond. Nearby, the historic Iron Belle Trail stretches east-west across the region, catering to hikers and bike enthusiasts seeking adventure through the scenic wilderness of the Upper Peninsula's Marquette County.
text3: The road and rail travel meet, offering scenic views of Little Twin Lakes and Norway Mountain in the industrial area. North of Norway, the US 45 freeway intersects with US 45 Alternate, creating a Y-intersection that directs traffic north towards Ishpeming and beyond. Close by, the Iron Belle Trail, a historic path that runs from east to west, provides opportunities for hikers and cyclists looking to explore the beautiful wilderness of Marquette County in the Upper Peninsula.

prefix: The Battle of Edson's Ridge, also known as the Battle of the Bloody Ridge, Battle of Raiders Ridge, and Battle of the Ridge, was a land battle of the Pacific campaign of World War II between Imperial Japanese Army and Allied (mainly United States Marine Corps) ground forces. It took place from 12–14 September 1942, on Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands, and was the second of three separate major Japanese ground offensives during the Guadalcanal campaign.
gold: In the battle, U.S. Marines, under the overall command of U.S. Major General Alexander Vandegrift, repulsed an attack by the Japanese 35th Infantry Brigade, under the command of Japanese Major General Kiyotake Kawaguchi. The Marines were defending the Lunga perimeter that guarded Henderson Field on Guadalcanal, which was captured from the Japanese by the Allies in landings on Guadalcanal on 7 August 1942. Kawaguchi's unit was sent to Guadalcanal in response to the Allied landings with the mission of recapturing the airfield and driving the Allied forces from the island. Underestimating the strength of Allied forces on Guadalcanal—about 12,000—Kawaguchi's 6,000 soldiers conducted several nighttime frontal assaults on the U.S. defenses. The main Japanese assault occurred around Lunga ridge south of Henderson Field, manned by troops from several U.S. Marine Corps units, primarily troops from the 1st Raider and 1st Parachute Battalions under U.S. Marine Corps Lieutenant Colonel Merritt A. Edson.
text1:
The battle began on September 12, 1942, when a Japanese force of around 2,000 troops, led by Lieutenant General Kiyotake Kawaguchi, attempted to flank and overwhelm the 1st Marine Regiment, which was occupying Edson's Ridge. The Japanese troops, who had been airlifted to Guadalcanal, were intent on capturing the airfield and driving the Allies off the island.

The Japanese force, which included experienced troops from the Imperial Japanese Army's 4th and 16th Independent Infantry Regiments, advanced under the cover of darkness, seeking to catch the Marines off guard. However, the Marines, who had been alerted to the impending attack, were well-prepared and entrenched on the ridge, with a strong defensive perimeter.

As the Japanese troops emerged from the darkness, they were met with a hail of machine gun fire and artillery shells, which severely disrupted their advance. Despite being heavily outnumbered, the Marines fought bravely, pinning down the Japanese troops with accurate fire and preventing them from gaining a foothold on the ridge.

Over the next two days, the battle raged on, with both sides suffering heavy casualties. The Japanese troops made repeated attempts to break through the Marine lines, but were repeatedly repelled. On the morning of September 14, the Japanese commander, General Kawaguchi, attempted to lead a final charge, but was himself wounded in the fighting.

As the Japanese troops began to falter and retreat, the Marines took advantage of the opportunity to launch a counterattack, pushing the Japanese forces back and capturing several key positions. By the end of the day, the battle was effectively over, with the Japanese troops having suffered heavy losses and withdrawing from the battlefield.

The Battle of Edson's Ridge was a significant Allied victory, marking a major turning point in the Guadalcanal campaign. The battle had demonstrated the determination and bravery of the US Marine Corps, and had dealt a significant blow to Japanese morale. In the weeks that followed, the Allies would continue to push forward, eventually securing control of Guadalcanal and paving the way for future operations in the Pacific.
text2:
The battle was sparked by a sustained attack on the Allied positions on Edson's Ridge, a strategically located hill that controlled access to the Matanikau River and its fertile valley. The Japanese, led by Major General Harukichi Hyakutake, aimed to dislodge the Marine Regimental Combat Team 1 (RTC1) from their entrenched positions and recapture the island. The Allies, consisting of the US 7th Marines and supporting forces, had established a strong defensive perimeter along Edson's Ridge, prepared to resist the expected attack.

On September 12, Japanese forces began a swift and stealthy advance, spearheaded by the 124th Independent Battalion, a renowned elite unit known for its tenacious fighting skills. The battalion commander, Lieutenant Colonel Ichiji Sugiyama, led his troops with a fanatical determination, using clever tactics and local terrain to their advantage. The Marines, dug in along Edson's Ridge, were caught off guard and took heavy casualties in the first wave of attacks.

Desperate to hold their ground, the Marines regrouped and launched a spirited counterattack under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Merritt A. "Red Mike" Edson, the battle's namesake. With valorous support from a battalion of Navy Seabees, Edson's weary troops managed to repel the Japanese attacks, inflicting significant losses on the enemy. The fighting raged on throughout the day, with neither side giving ground.

By nightfall, the Japanese had exhausted themselves, and their momentum had waned. The Marines, exhausted and battered, held firm on Edson's Ridge, but knew their precarious position was unsustainable. Reinforcements were urgently needed to bolster the Allied defenses, and General Alexander Vandegrift, the commander of the Marine Expeditionary Force, quickly dispatched the US 1st Marine Regiment to the island. The arrival of fresh troops revitalized the Allied defenses, and on September 14, the Japanese launched a final, futile assault. Weary and outnumbered, the Marines successfully defended Edson's Ridge, earning the battle's infamy as the costliest in terms of casualties on the island. The outcome of the battle had turned the tide in favor of the Allied forces, setting the stage for a prolonged and grueling struggle for Guadalcanal.
text3: The conflict began with a prolonged assault on the Allied positions on Edson's Ridge, a hill strategically positioned to control access to the Matanikau River and its fertile valley. Major General Harukichi Hyakutake led the Japanese in an attempt to remove the Marine Regimental Combat Team 1 (RTC1) from their fortified positions and reclaim the island. The US 7th Marines and their allies had set up a solid defense on Edson's Ridge, ready to fend off the anticipated assault. Japanese forces, led by the 124th Independent Battalion, launched a quick and sneaky attack on September 12. Lieutenant Colonel Ichiji Sugiyama led his troops with determination, utilizing clever tactics and the local terrain to their advantage. The initial wave of attacks caught the entrenched Marines on Edson's Ridge by surprise, resulting in significant casualties. The Marines, determined to maintain their position, rallied together and launched a strong counteroffensive led by Lieutenant Colonel Merritt A. "Red Mike" Edson, for whom the battle was named. Assisted by a battalion of Navy Seabees, Edson's exhausted soldiers successfully fought off the Japanese assaults, causing heavy casualties to the enemy forces. Both sides continued to battle fiercely without yielding any territory. The Japanese had worn themselves out by the end of the day, and their progress had slowed down. Despite their exhaustion and injuries, the Marines maintained their stronghold on Edson's Ridge, recognizing the fragility of their situation. General Alexander Vandegrift promptly sent the US 1st Marine Regiment to the island to strengthen the Allied defenses. Fresh troops arriving boosted the Allied defenses, leading to a final unsuccessful Japanese attack on September 14. Despite being tired and facing superior numbers, the Marines managed to protect Edson's Ridge, resulting in the battle being known for the high number of casualties suffered on the island. The battle's result shifted the advantage to the Allied forces, initiating a tough and extended fight for Guadalcanal.

prefix: The reactions of the native Aboriginal inhabitants to the sudden arrival of British settlers in Australia were varied, but were inevitably hostile when the settlers' presence led to competition over resources, and to the occupation of the indigenous inhabitants' lands. European diseases decimated Aboriginal populations, and the occupation or destruction of lands and food resources sometimes led to starvation.
gold: By and large neither the British nor the Aborigines approached the conflict in an organised sense and conflict occurred between groups of settlers and individual tribes rather than systematic warfare. At times, however, the frontier wars did see the involvement of British soldiers and later mounted police units. Not all Aboriginal groups resisted white encroachment on their lands, while many Aborigines served in mounted police units and were involved in attacks on other tribes. Fighting between Aborigines and Europeans was localised as the Aborigines did not form confederations capable of sustained resistance. As a result, there was not a single war, but rather a series of violent engagements and massacres across the continent. Organised or disorganised however, a pattern of frontier warfare emerged with Aboriginal resistance beginning in the 18th century and continuing into the early 20th century. This warfare contradicts the popular and at times academic "myth" of peaceful settlement in Australia. Faced with Aboriginal resistance settlers often reacted with violence, resulting in a number of indiscriminate massacres. Among the most famous is the Battle of Pinjarra in Western Australia in 1834. Such incidents were not officially sanctioned however, and after the Myall Creek massacre in New South Wales in 1838 seven Europeans were hanged for their part in the killings. However, in Tasmania the so-called Black War was fought between 1828 and 1832, and aimed at driving most of the island's native inhabitants onto a number of isolated peninsulas. Although it began in failure for the British, it ultimately resulted in considerable casualties amongst the native population. It may be inaccurate though to depict the conflict as one sided and mainly perpetrated by Europeans on Aborigines. Although many more Aborigines died than British, this may have had more to do with the technological and logistic advantages enjoyed by the Europeans. Aboriginal tactics varied, but were mainly based on pre-existing hunting and fighting practices—using spears, clubs and other primitive weapons. Unlike the indigenous peoples of New Zealand and North America, on the main Aborigines failed to adapt to meet the challenge of the Europeans. Although there were some instances of individuals and groups acquiring and using firearms, this was not widespread.
text1:
As the British settlers continued to arrive in large numbers, the Aboriginal people were faced with the devastating consequences of cultural erosion.
