Over time, the Church of St. Lligwy underwent changes such as the installation of stained glass windows and a tower, yet its core mission of fostering the spiritual well-being of the islanders and fostering a sense of unity remained unchanged.

prefix: I just thought it was time for my character to go". Ferrell initially called the producers and offered to appear in Carell's last season, because he is "a fan and wanted to commemorate Carell’s swan song".
gold: He had previously starred alongside Carell, in the 2004 film, Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy. The Season Seven DVD contains a number of deleted scenes from this episode. The cut scenes include a sequence in which Michael and Deangelo discuss cancer jokes and the 2010 film Megamind—an animated film that featured the voice of Ferrell—while drinking vodka, shots of Michael and Deangelo discussing their enjoyment for coffee, and Dwight attempting to appease his new boss. In its original American broadcast, "Training Day" was viewed by an estimated 7.871 million viewers and received a 4.0 rating/11% share among adults between the ages of 18 and 49. This means that it was seen by 4.0% of all 18- to 49-year-olds, and 11% of all 18- to 49-year-olds watching television at the time of the broadcast. This marked a rise in the ratings from the previous episode, "Garage Sale", which can be attributed to Ferrell's guest appearance. The episode ranked first in its timeslot, beating the Fox crime drama Bones, which scored a 3.5/10 percent relating in the 18–49 demographic; a rerun of the ABC medical drama Grey's Anatomy and a rerun of the CBS crime drama CSI: Crime Scene Investigation. "Training Day" received mixed reviews from television critics. IGN writer Cindy White wrote that Deangelo was not given a proper introduction and that he was not distinguished from Michael's character. She also went on to criticize Jim, Pam and Dwight's reaction to Deangelo as the new manager, particular that of Jim and Pam, writing that "it's becoming painfully obvious that the longtime writers don't know what to do with them anymore". However, she concluded that the episode continued the seventh season's improvement over the sixth, and that it showed potential for future episodes of the season. She ultimately gave the episode a 7.5 out of 10 rating, denoting a "good" episode. The A.V. Club reviewer Myles McNutt praised Michael's reactions to the office easily ignoring him for Deangelo, calling the final shot of him walking into his office alone "quite effective", and that Dwight's reaction to not being suggested to be Michael's replacement made it more "meaningful".
text1:
The producers, touched by Ferrell's kind gesture, quickly accepted his offer. "We were blown away by his generosity and sense of camaraderie," said a production source. "Steve and Will have always had a special bond, and this was the perfect way to celebrate their friendship and the end of an era on the show."

Ferrell, true to his word, made a surprise appearance in Carell's final episode, reprising his iconic character as the eccentric and lovable Ron Swanson. The two actors shared a heartfelt goodbye scene, with Carell's character thanking Ferrell's for being a constant source of support and inspiration throughout his time on the show.

The emotional reunion left the entire cast and crew in tears, and the episode's finale was met with a standing ovation. "It was a truly unforgettable moment," said Carell in a post-show interview. "I'm so grateful to have Steve as a friend and to have had the opportunity to share this experience with him.
text2:
The gesture didn't go unnoticed by the producers, who were touched by Ferrell's willingness to pay homage to their departing star. They quickly accepted the offer, and a script was hastily crafted for a cameo that would allow Ferrell to join Will Ferrell's character, Ron Swanson, for a memorable episode.

Carell, who was initially surprised by Ferrell's phone call, couldn't have been more grateful for the gesture. "It's an honor to work with him again," Carell said in an interview. "We've always had a lot of fun together, and I knew he would come up with a hilarious idea for our swan song together."

The resulting episode became one of the most popular in the show's history, with fans and critics alike praising the chemistry and comedy that once again flowed effortlessly between the two leads. As they filmed their scenes together, the camaraderie between Carell and Ferrell was palpable, and their improv-filled interactions brought the whole crew to their knees in laughter.

"Getting to work with Steve for one last time was a real blessing," Carell said, smiling wistfully during an interview. "We've come a long way from our early days on Saturday Night Live, but some friendships just don't fade away."

For Ferrell, the opportunity to pay homage to Carell was a small price for a chance to join his friend for one final romp in the fictional world of Pawnee. "Hey, I just wanted to give him a kick out the door, and a memorable one at that," he chuckled. "We may not always agree on the best kind of meat or the best kind of glassblowing, but we share something deep - a passion for making people laugh."

The two friends would eventually reconnect on various projects over the years, but the shared experience of their farewell to The Office remains an unforgettable highlight in both of their careers, a testament to the power of friendship and comedy to bring us together, even as we say goodbye.
text3: The producers noticed the gesture and were moved by Ferrell's tribute to their departing star. They agreed to the offer right away and rushed to create a script for Ferrell to make a cameo appearance alongside Will Ferrell's character, Ron Swanson, in a memorable episode. Carell was pleasantly surprised by Ferrell's phone call and deeply appreciative of the gesture. Carell expressed his gratitude for the opportunity to collaborate with Ferrell once more. I knew he would come up with a funny idea for our final collaboration. The episode that followed was highly acclaimed by both fans and critics for the seamless chemistry and comedy between the two main actors. The chemistry between Carell and Ferrell was evident during filming, with their improvised interactions causing the crew to burst into laughter. During an interview, Carell expressed his gratitude for the opportunity to collaborate with Steve one last time. Despite the passage of time since our days on Saturday Night Live, certain friendships remain strong and enduring. Ferrell saw honoring Carell as a small sacrifice in exchange for the chance to reunite with his friend in Pawnee for one last adventure. He chuckled as he mentioned wanting to give him a memorable send-off. While we may have differing opinions on certain topics, our shared love for comedy unites us on a deeper level. Their farewell to The Office remains a memorable highlight in both of their careers, showcasing the enduring power of friendship and comedy to unite them even as they part ways.

prefix: Tikal counterattacked against Dos Pilas in 672, driving B'alaj Chan K'awiil into an exile that lasted five years. Calakmul tried to encircle Tikal within an area dominated by its allies, such as El Peru, Dos Pilas, and Caracol.
gold: In 682, Jasaw Chan K'awiil I erected the first dated monument at Tikal in 120 years and claimed the title of kaloomte, so ending the hiatus. He initiated a programme of new construction and turned the tables on Calakmul when, in 695, he captured the enemy noble and threw the enemy state into a long decline from which it never fully recovered. After this, Calakmul never again erected a monument celebrating a military victory. By the 7th century, there was no active Teotihuacan presence at any Maya site and the center of Teotihuacan had been razed by 700. Even after this, formal war attire illustrated on monuments was Teotihuacan style. Jasaw Chan K'awiil I and his heir Yik'in Chan K'awiil continued hostilities against Calakmul and its allies and imposed firm regional control over the area around Tikal, extending as far as the territory around Lake Petén Itzá. These two rulers were responsible for much of the impressive architecture visible today. In 738, Quiriguá, a vassal of Copán, Tikal's key ally in the south, switched allegiance to Calakmul, defeated Copán and gained its own independence. It appears that this was a conscious effort on the part of Calakmul to bring about the collapse of Tikal's southern allies. This upset the balance of power in the southern Maya area and lead to a steady decline in the fortunes of Copán. In the 8th century, the rulers of Tikal collected monuments from across the city and erected them in front of the North Acropolis. By the late 8th century and early 9th century, activity at Tikal slowed. Impressive architecture was still built but few hieroglyphic inscriptions refer to later rulers. By the 9th century, the crisis of the Classic Maya collapse was sweeping across the region, with populations plummeting and city after city falling into silence. Increasingly endemic warfare in the Maya region caused Tikal's supporting population to heavily concentrate close to the city itself, accelerating the use of intensive agriculture and the corresponding environmental decline.
text1:
Despite being exiled, B'alaj Chan K'awiil continued to plot against Tikal from afar. He formed alliances with other rival cities, including the powerful city of Calakmul, and began to secretly gather forces to launch a counterattack against his former capital. Meanwhile, Tikal's leaders became complacent in their victory, believing that they had finally silenced their rival once and for all.

However, in 677, B'alaj Chan K'awiil returned from exile, armed with a new alliance and a burning desire for revenge. He led a massive army against Tikal, joined by forces from Calakmul, Dos Pilas, and Caracol. The combined armies laid siege to Tikal, and the city's defenders found themselves vastly outnumbered and outgunned.

The battle was fierce and intense, with both sides suffering heavy losses. But in the end, B'alaj Chan K'awiil's determination and cunning proved too much for Tikal. The city was breached, and its leaders were forced to flee, leaving their once-great capital to be sacked and plundered by their enemies.

The defeat was a devastating blow to Tikal, and it marked the beginning of a period of decline and fragmentation for the city. B'alaj Chan K'awiil, meanwhile, solidified his position as the dominant leader of the region, and his city, Calakmul, became the new epicenter of power and influence. The rivalry between Tikal and Calakmul would continue to rage for generations, but for now, Calakmul had emerged victorious.
text2:
Meanwhile, the divisions among the Itza Maya, led by Jasaw Chan K'awiil I, intensified. His rival, Yuknoom Yich'aak K'ak', continued to gain influence, and his supporters began to question Jasaw's right to rule. As tensions rose, Yuknoom Yich'aak K'ak' saw an opportunity to strike at Tikal's weakened state. He formed an alliance with Calakmul and its allies, including El Peru, Dos Pilas, and Caracol, and launched a surprise attack on Tikal in 677. The Itza Maya were caught off guard, and Jasaw Chan K'awiil I was forced to flee to the southern lakes of Tabasco.

Tikal, reeling from the sudden assault, attempted to regroup under the leadership of Jasaw's trusted advisor, Ahkin Chan Awak. However, the city's defenses had been breached, and its people had lost valuable time. Calakmul and its allies were now firmly established on Tikal's borders, and Ahkin was faced with the daunting task of rebuilding his city and preparing for future conflicts. The stage was set for a prolonged struggle for dominance between the two powers, with the Itza Maya and their Calakmul allies locked in a battle that would rage for nearly a decade.
text3: At the same time, the conflicts within the Itza Maya, under the leadership of Jasaw Chan K'awiil I, grew stronger. Yuknoom Yich'aak K'ak' gained more power and his followers started to doubt Jasaw's legitimacy as a leader. With tensions escalating, Yuknoom Yich'aak K'ak' took advantage of Tikal's vulnerability to make a move. In 677, he joined forces with Calakmul and its allies like El Peru, Dos Pilas, and Caracol, and unexpectedly attacked Tikal. Jasaw Chan K'awiil and the Itza Maya were surprised by the attack. I had to escape to the lakes in Tabasco to seek safety. After the unexpected attack, Tikal tried to recover with the help of Jasaw's loyal advisor, Ahkin Chan Awak. Nevertheless, the city had been infiltrated and its residents had wasted precious time. Calakmul and its allies had solidified their presence near Tikal, leaving Ahkin with the challenging job of rebuilding the city and getting ready for upcoming battles. A long-lasting battle for supremacy between the Itza Maya and their Calakmul allies was about to begin and would last for almost ten years.

prefix: Richmond grew up in Ashland, Ohio. His parents, Al and Evelyn (née Warner) Richmond, met in the course of their work.
gold: Al was a welder for pipe construction companies and Evelyn was a field office manager. Noticing that highway crews had to dig up the entire highway to lay pipe, Al designed a machine to bore underneath the highway. To market this invention, he founded Richmond Manufacturing, which eventually exported machines worldwide. Tim's driving days started as a toddler when he was given a go-kart that he often drove inside buildings and across his lawn. He later raced the kart at tracks in Moreland and New Pittsburg. Richmond grew up in a well-to-do family, and was sometimes therefore treated differently by his classmates, so his parents enrolled him in Miami Military Academy in Miami, Florida. During his years in Miami, Tim and his mother moved to Florida and his father stayed in Ohio. While home in Ohio over a summer break, he met local drag racer Raymond Beadle through lifelong friend Fred Miller. When Richmond reached age 16, his parents purchased him a Pontiac Trans Am, a speedboat and a Piper Cherokee airplane for his birthday. Yet his mother Evelyn often worried about spoiling her only son. She once said, "Tim was lazy...", and "... I did everything for him. I ruined him, I admit it. He was my whole life." Richmond excelled in sports; he set a conference record in high hurdles and his high school football career was stellar enough that the academy retired his sports jersey after his gridiron days were over. Miami Military Academy named him Athlete of the Year in 1970. Richmond's other interests included flying, and he earned his private pilot license at age 16. Following high school graduation, Richmond attended Ashland University for about one year before dropping out. A friend of Richmond's father co-owned a sprint car and Richmond joined the team as a crew member for Dave Shoemaker. In 1976, 21-year-old Richmond took the car onto Lakeville Speedway at Lakeville, Ohio for some practice laps. "Somebody put a stopwatch on me," Richmond said. "I was running laps faster than Dave had been. It was the first time I had ever driven a race car." Richmond and his father found a red, white and blue-colored No. 98 car in Pennsylvania, which was the same number and paint scheme that Richmond used on model cars as a child. In his first competition at the track, officials placed Richmond in the slowest heat. He passed several cars before spinning out and breaking an axle. Although he made several attempts to get the car pointed in the right direction, the broken axle prevented the car from driving straight.
text1: His father, Al, was a machinist at a local factory, while his mother, Evelyn, was a schoolteacher at the same school where Richmond would later attend elementary school. Despite their busy schedules, they made sure to prioritize family time and would often take Richmond and his younger sister, Amy, on weekend outings to the nearby Hocking Hills, where they would hike and explore the natural beauty of the area. Growing up in Ashland, Richmond was exposed to a strong sense of community and small-town values that would later influence his work and worldview.
text2: His father, Al, was a chemist at a local manufacturing plant, while his mother, Evelyn, worked as a biologist at a nearby university. They met at a professional conference, where Evelyn was presenting a research paper and Al was in the audience, impressed by her expertise in the field. They struck up a conversation over coffee, and their conversation flowed as smoothly as the coffee they sipped. They quickly discovered a shared passion for science and a commitment to making a positive impact in their community. Before parting ways, Al asked Evelyn to join him for dinner and a movie that weekend, and their romance blossomed from that moment on.
text3: Al, his father, worked as a chemist at a local manufacturing plant, and his mother, Evelyn, was a biologist at a nearby university. At a professional conference, Al was captivated by Evelyn's knowledge and expertise in the field as she presented a research paper. They had a smooth-flowing conversation over coffee. They soon realized they both had a strong interest in science and a desire to contribute positively to their community. Their romance began to flourish after Al invited Evelyn to dinner and a movie that weekend before they said goodbye.

prefix: Some second- or third-hand accounts of Tikal appeared in print starting in the 17th century, continuing through the writings of John Lloyd Stephens in the early 19th century (Stephens and his illustrator Frederick Catherwood heard rumors of a lost city, with white building tops towering above the jungle, during their 1839-40 travels in the region). Because of the site's remoteness from modern towns, however, no explorers visited Tikal until Modesto Méndez and Ambrosio Tut, respectively the commissioner and the governor of Petén, visited it in 1848.
gold: Artist Eusebio Lara accompanied them and their account was published in Germany in 1853. Several other expeditions came to further investigate, map, and photograph Tikal in the 19th century (including Alfred P. Maudslay in 1881-82) and the early 20th century. Pioneering archaeologists started to clear, map and record the ruins in the 1880s. In 1951, a small airstrip was built at the ruins, which previously could only be reached by several days' travel through the jungle on foot or mule. In 1956 the Tikal project began to map the city on a scale not previously seen in the Maya area. From 1956 through 1970, major archaeological excavations were carried out by the University of Pennsylvania Tikal Project. They mapped much of the site and excavated and restored many of the structures. Excavations directed by Edwin M. Shook and later by William Coe of the university investigated the North Acropolis and the Central Plaza from 1957 to 1969. The Tikal Project recorded over 200 monuments at the site. In 1979, the Guatemalan government began a further archeological project at Tikal, which continued through to 1984. Filmmaker George Lucas used Tikal as a filming location for the fictional planetary moeleased Star Wars film, Episode IV: A New Hope, which premiered in 1977.StarWars.com Temple I at Tikal was featured on the reverse of the 50 centavo banknote. Eon Productions used the site for the James Bond film Moonraker. Tikal is now a major tourist attraction surrounded by its own national park. A site museum has been built at Tikal; it was completed in 1964. Tikal has been partially restored by the University of Pennsylvania and the government of Guatemala. It was one of the largest of the Classic period Maya cities and was one of the largest cities in the Americas. The architecture of the ancient city is built from limestone and includes the remains of temples that tower over high, large royal palaces, in addition to a number of smaller pyramids, palaces, residences, administrative buildings, platforms and inscribed stone monuments.Drew 1999, p.183.
text1:
After Méndez and Tut's visit, Tikal remained largely forgotten by the outside world, its ancient temples and plazas overgrown with jungle vegetation. It wasn't until the early 20th century that the site began to gain attention from archaeologists and explorers once again. In 1926, a team led by American archaeologist Earl H. Morris arrived at Tikal, followed by a series of subsequent expeditions in the 1950s and 1960s. These efforts led to a greater understanding of the site's history and significance, including the discovery of numerous stelae and hieroglyphics.

In the 1970s, the Guatemalan government established Tikal National Park, which has since worked to protect and preserve the site. Today, Tikal is one of the most famous and iconic ancient Maya cities, attracting thousands of visitors each year. Despite the passage of time, the site's grand architecture and lush surroundings still evoke the mystery and grandeur of the ancient civilization that once flourished here.
text2:
In the late 19th century, the discovery of Tikal by Modesto Méndez and Ambrosio Tut marked the beginning of a new era of archaeological exploration. The site, shrouded in mystery for centuries, was suddenly brought into the spotlight. News of the ancient ruins spread quickly throughout Central America and beyond, drawing the interest of scientists, adventurers, and treasure seekers.

Dr. Edward Thompson, a renowned archaeologist from the United States, led a team of expeditions to Tikal in the late 1890s and early 1900s, recovering artifacts and making significant contributions to the understanding of Mayan culture. His findings, including intricate ceramics, jade jewelry, and sophisticated ballgame courts, further fueled public fascination with the ancient civilization.

Meanwhile, the newly formed Academy of Sciences in Guatemala, led by Dr. Alfonso LaFarge, also conducted extensive research at Tikal. The academy's efforts helped establish the site as a protected archaeological zone, and a small settlement of archaeologists, locals, and support staff grew around the temple complexes.

By the mid-20th century, international efforts began to focus on preserving and excavating the sprawling city. The Guatemalan government officially declared Tikal a national monument in 1976, and UNESCO designated it as a World Heritage Site in 1979. Today, Tikal National Park, with its towering temples and mystical atmosphere, attracts hundreds of thousands of tourists and archaeology enthusiasts, making it one of the world's most popular and awe-inspiring ancient ruins.
text3: The finding of Tikal by Modesto Méndez and Ambrosio Tut in the late 19th century initiated a new period of archaeological investigation. The previously mysterious site of Tikal was suddenly illuminated. Word of the ancient ruins quickly traveled across Central America and beyond, capturing the attention of scientists, explorers, and fortune hunters. Dr. Edward Thompson, a well-known American archaeologist, conducted expeditions to Tikal in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, uncovering artifacts and advancing knowledge of Mayan culture. His discoveries, such as detailed pottery, jade ornaments, and advanced ball courts, continued to increase interest in the ancient society. At the same time, Dr. Alfonso LaFarge and the Academy of Sciences in Guatemala were actively researching Tikal. The academy's work led to the site being designated as a protected archaeological area, leading to the development of a community of archaeologists, locals, and support personnel near the temple structures. International initiatives in the mid-20th century shifted towards the preservation and excavation of the expansive city. In 1976, Tikal was declared a national monument by the Guatemalan government and designated as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1979. Tikal National Park is now a popular destination for tourists and archaeology enthusiasts due to its impressive temples and captivating ambiance.

prefix: Even after this, formal war attire illustrated on monuments was Teotihuacan style. Jasaw Chan K'awiil I and his heir Yik'in Chan K'awiil continued hostilities against Calakmul and its allies and imposed firm regional control over the area around Tikal, extending as far as the territory around Lake Petén Itzá.
gold: These two rulers were responsible for much of the impressive architecture visible today. In 738, Quiriguá, a vassal of Copán, Tikal's key ally in the south, switched allegiance to Calakmul, defeated Copán and gained its own independence. It appears that this was a conscious effort on the part of Calakmul to bring about the collapse of Tikal's southern allies. This upset the balance of power in the southern Maya area and lead to a steady decline in the fortunes of Copán. In the 8th century, the rulers of Tikal collected monuments from across the city and erected them in front of the North Acropolis. By the late 8th century and early 9th century, activity at Tikal slowed. Impressive architecture was still built but few hieroglyphic inscriptions refer to later rulers. By the 9th century, the crisis of the Classic Maya collapse was sweeping across the region, with populations plummeting and city after city falling into silence. Increasingly endemic warfare in the Maya region caused Tikal's supporting population to heavily concentrate close to the city itself, accelerating the use of intensive agriculture and the corresponding environmental decline. Construction continued at the beginning of the century, with the erection of Temple 3, the last of the city's major pyramids, and the erection of monuments to mark the 19th K'atun in 810. The beginning of the 10th Bak'tun in 830 passed uncelebrated, and marks the beginning of a 60-year hiatus, probably resulting from the collapse of central control in the city. During this hiatus, satellite sites traditionally under Tikal's control began to erect their own monuments featuring local rulers and using the Mutal emblem glyph, with Tikal apparently lacking the authority or the power to crush these bids for independence. In 849, Jewel K'awiil is mentioned on a stela at Seibal as visiting that city as the Divine Lord of Tikal but he is not recorded elsewhere and Tikal's once-great power was little more than a memory. The sites of Ixlu and Jimbal had by now inherited the once exclusive Mutal emblem glyph. As Tikal and its hinterland reached peak population, the area suffered deforestation, erosion and nutrient loss followed by a rapid decline in population levels.
text1:
As the reigns of Jasaw Chan K'awiil I and Yik'in Chan K'awiil came to a close, the city of Tikal continued to thrive, with its rich cultural heritage and powerful monarchs leaving a lasting legacy. The once-warlike atmosphere began to shift, and the focus turned to diplomatic efforts and trade with neighboring cities. Tikal's artisans and merchants became renowned for their exquisite crafts and luxurious goods, which were highly prized throughout the region.

Meanwhile, the rulers of Calakmul, still seething from their past defeats, began to plot a new course of action. They forged alliances with other rival cities, seeking to weaken Tikal's grip on the region. The stage was set for a new era of conflict, as the two great powers of the region prepared to clash once more.

As tensions mounted, a young and ambitious king, Chak Toh Ich'aak I, ascended to the throne of Tikal. With a burning desire to prove himself and secure his place in history, he vowed to assert his city's dominance and crush the ambitions of Calakmul once and for all. The fate of Tikal, and the future of the region, hung in the balance as Chak Toh Ich'aak I prepared to unleash a new wave of conquest and glory upon the ancient world.
text2:
As the reign of Yik'in Chan K'awiil came to an end, he passed the throne to his son, who would become the renowned ruler, K'an B'alan. During his reign, K'an B'alan oversaw significant architectural achievements, including the construction of the impressive Temple I, a grand pyramidal structure dedicated to the god Ah-Chaun-Tikum. The temple's construction was a testament to the city's continued prosperity and its people's skill as master masons and sculptors. The temple's ornate carvings, depicting scenes of warfare, agriculture, and ritual sacrifice, have been studied extensively by archaeologists, providing valuable insight into the city's complex social hierarchy and cosmology.

Meanwhile, the city's relationships with its neighboring kingdoms remained tense, with frequent skirmishes occurring along the borders. However, a period of relative peace did emerge under K'an B'alan's rule, allowing the city to focus on internal development and trade. The Petén lakeside became a thriving center for regional commerce, with merchants arriving from as far away as the Gulf Coast and Mexico's central highlands. The influx of foreign goods and knowledge helped to accelerate cultural diversification within Tikal, incorporating elements such as ceramics, weavings, and metallurgic practices from various parts of the region.

As the reign of K'an B'alan came to an end, he passed the throne to his son, who would become the last ruler of the Early Classic period at Tikal. The new ruler, who would take on the name Lady Sacred Wildflower, was a skilled diplomat and strategist. She worked tirelessly to maintain alliances with neighboring kingdoms and to promote trade and commerce within the region. Despite the city's continued success, Lady Sacred Wildflower would ultimately face challenges from rival powers and environmental disasters that would threaten the very foundations of the city-state.
text3: Yik'in Chan K'awiil passed the throne to his son, K'an B'alan, who would become a famous ruler. K'an B'alan supervised the building of Temple I, a large pyramid dedicated to the god Ah-Chaun-Tikum, during his rule. The building of the temple showcased the city's ongoing success and the expertise of its residents in masonry and sculpture. Archaeologists have extensively studied the intricate carvings on the temple, which depict various aspects of life in the city and offer insight into its social structure and beliefs. At the same time, the city continued to have strained relationships with nearby kingdoms, leading to frequent border skirmishes. During K'an B'alan's reign, the city experienced a time of peace that enabled it to prioritize internal growth and commerce. Merchants from distant regions, such as the Gulf Coast and Mexico's central highlands, traveled to the Petén lakeside, which flourished as a hub for regional trade. The introduction of foreign goods and expertise led to increased cultural diversity in Tikal, integrating ceramics, textiles, and metalworking techniques from different areas. K'an B'alan's successor, who would be the final ruler of the Early Classic period in Tikal, took the throne as his reign ended. Lady Sacred Wildflower, the new ruler, was adept at diplomacy and military tactics. She put in a lot of effort to uphold alliances with nearby kingdoms and boost trade and business in the area. Lady Sacred Wildflower encountered obstacles from rival powers and natural disasters that posed a threat to the city-state's stability.

prefix: For me it's about more than turning up and saying the lines. It's about understanding it and trying to make it better.
gold: That's actually a lot of fun. What's great is nobody says, 'Just shut up.' They want you to work at it. [...] I surprise myself sometimes because after two and a half years sometimes I see friends on the side of a poster and I think, 'do I want to do something else?' but I really like this job, I never get that awful ‘dread’ feeling when you really don’t want to go into work." In October 2008, Ayola announced that she would be departing from Holby City in order to have a second child, stating: "I've had a great time and I'll miss it. I made the decision purely because I was pregnant, but I wasn't really ready to put down the character of Kyla. I'm very sorry to have to let her go." Throughout her career, Ayola has been outspoken on the subject of racial discrimination in the entertainment industry. Describing her motivation, she states: "I am not an overtly political person. I just want fairness". Ayola believes that black actors receive less recognition than their white counterparts, explaining; "If you get a show with six stars and one is black you are more likely to see interviews with the five white actors. [...] They are not being sold as a reason to watch." She believes that her career would have taken her in a different direction were she not of ethnic origin, stating: "I could not have played any of the roles I have played on TV if I was white [...] I am very aware of where the glass ceiling is and it's still very low and expectations are still very low". She has noted having casting directors accept the notion of characters being both black and Welsh to be a particular problem, explaining that: "I get offered a lot of very different roles, but they're never Welsh. [...] The one time I was asked to play a Welsh character on screen was in Tiger Bay for BBC Wales, but I know if that series had been called Radyr Park or Cyncoed Close I wouldn't have been in it". In 2001, Ayola founded a production company and directed a short film entitled Persephone's Playground. She presented the film at the Cannes film festival, using it as part of her campaign for increased black representation in theatre, films and television. The project, however, was largely unsuccessful, with Ayola stating: "it just made me decide that if there's anything I don't want to do, it's produce films, because I'm rubbish at it.
text1:
It's about immersing myself in the character's psyche, to truly grasp their motivations and emotions. It's about finding the nuances that make them relatable, and bringing those to life in every performance. I'm not just a vessel for the words on the page, I'm a storyteller, and my job is to craft a narrative that resonates with the audience.

I remember when I first started acting, I was so focused on just getting the lines right, on reciting the words correctly. But as I grew as an artist, I realized that it's so much more than that. It's about understanding the context, the history, the relationships between characters. It's about finding the humanity in the story, and sharing that with the audience.

When I'm on set, I'm fully present, fully focused. I'm not thinking about my next line, I'm thinking about why my character is saying it. I'm thinking about what's driving them, what's motivating them. And that's when the magic happens. That's when the words on the page start to feel like real, living, breathing emotions.

It's not just about turning up and saying the lines, it's about becoming the character. It's about losing myself in the story, and finding myself in the process. It's about creating something authentic, something true, and sharing that with the world.
text2: As an actor, I think it's easy to fall into the trap of just showing up to work and reciting your lines without putting any real thought into the character or the story. But for me, it's not about just phoning it in and hoping no one notices. It's about immersing myself in the world of the play, and finding ways to bring depth and nuance to the character.
text3: I believe it's common for actors to simply go through the motions of performing without truly understanding their character or the story. I don't believe in just going through the motions and pretending like everything is fine. I aim to fully engage with the play's world and add complexity to the character.

prefix: Hearing of Warbrick's plans, public servant Thomas Eyton contacted him to offer help managing the tour, which Warbrick accepted. When James Scott, a publican, subsequently joined the partnership, the three men decided that Warbrick would be the team's captain, Scott its manager and Eyton its promoter.
gold: Warbrick started assembling a team for the tour in early 1888. He had difficulties assembling a squad due to player availability, and failed to secure the talented Jack Taiaroa due to his university commitments. Some Māori players who initially agreed to play later pulled out when the eligibility criteria were relaxed to allow squad members who were only part-Māori. Twenty Māori or part-Māori players joined the squad; five Pākehā (white New Zealand) players were added after the team lost to Auckland. Due to the inclusion of these Pākehā players the team was renamed from the "New Zealand Maori" to the "New Zealand Native Football Representatives". The final squad comprised 26 players (including Warbrick); of these at least five were full-blooded Māori, while fourteen had a Māori mother and a Pākehā father. The parentage of some of the players is unknown. The team toured New Zealand before departing overseas, playing against Hawke's Bay, Auckland, Nelson, Wellington, Canterbury, South Canterbury, and Otago. The first game was contested against Hawke's Bay in Napier on 23 June 1888. They played nine games in their preliminary tour of New Zealand, and won seven of them. Their last New Zealand match before departure, against Otago played in Dunedin on 31 July 1888, was won by one try to nil. The team sailed for Australia from Dunedin, leaving on 1 August 1888. In Melbourne, Scott recruited Jack Lawlor to train the players in Victorian Rules football in Britain as preparation for possible Victorian Rules matches on their return to Australia. The team played two rugby matches against the Melbourne Rugby Union team, winning the first and drawing the second, before continuing to Britain via Suez. They arrived in London on 27 September 1888. The team were met in Britain by local rugby administrators, including an official of England's Rugby Football Union (RFU). The first match of the tour was against Surrey, where the team became the first New Zealand side to perform a haka, and also the first to wear an all black uniform. That the team was predominantly Māori provoked curiosity from the British press – at the time, most Britons had not seen non-white people – but there was some surprise that the team were not as "Māori" as had been expected.
text1:
With their roles established, the trio set out to assemble a team of skilled players to accompany Warbrick on the tour. They held tryouts in the local area, inviting anyone with cricketing ability to come and show off their skills. Among the many applicants was a young player named John Jackson, who impressed the trio with his aggressive batting style and lightning-quick reflexes. Warbrick, Scott, and Eyton were so impressed that they offered Jackson a spot on the team, and he quickly became a fan favorite due to his charismatic personality and impressive on-field antics.

As the team began to take shape, Warbrick, Scott, and Eyton turned their attention to the logistics of the tour. They arranged for the team to travel by horse and carriage, with a coachman and two horses to transport the players and their equipment. They also booked rooms at local inns and taverns along the route, where the team could rest and refuel between matches.

The tour kicked off with a match against a local team in a small village, and the crowd was electric as Warbrick and his team took to the field. Warbrick, as captain, won the toss and elected to bat, and Jackson immediately set the tone with a blistering innings of 50 runs in just 30 minutes. The home team struggled to respond, and the visitors ran out comfortable winners by 100 runs.

The win set the tone for the rest of the tour, and the team went on to win match after match, drawing in large crowds and earning a reputation as one of the most exciting and talented teams in the country. As they traveled from town to town, Warbrick, Scott, and Eyton worked tirelessly behind the scenes to ensure that everything ran smoothly, and their hard work paid off as the team's popularity continued to grow.
text2:
With the team's organizational structure in place, the three partners got to work preparing for the tour. Eyton, with his experience in the public sector, leveraged his connections to secure sponsorships and funding for the team, while Scott managed the logistics, from arranging accommodations and transportation to coordinating the team's itinerary. As captain, Warbrick worked tirelessly to ensure the team was physically and mentally prepared, leading rigorous training sessions and motivating his teammates.

Meanwhile, the team's roster began to take shape, with a mix of veteran players from various local clubs and young talent from the region. As the departure date approached, the team traveled to the nearby city, where they would launch their historic tour. With Warbrick at the helm, the team was filled with excitement and nerves, knowing that their reputation as the first-ever touring rugby team in the region was riding on the outcome of their journeys.

On a sunny afternoon, the team gathered in the city square, where a crowd of curious onlookers awaited their departure. With Warbrick leading the way, the team boarded the coach, a sturdy vehicle that would carry them to the first leg of their journey. As the coach set off, the team waved goodbye to the crowd, knowing that their names and faces were now embarking on a journey of a lifetime, with the potential to forge their legacies and shape the future of the sport in the region.
text3: The three partners began preparing for the tour once the team's organizational structure was established. Eyton used his public sector experience to secure sponsorships and funding, while Scott handled all the logistics for the team's tour. Warbrick, as the team captain, put in a lot of effort to make sure the team was ready both physically and mentally, running intense training sessions and inspiring his teammates. At the same time, the team's lineup started to form, including experienced players from different local clubs and promising young talent from the area. The team journeyed to a nearby city as they neared the start of their groundbreaking tour. Under Warbrick's leadership, the team felt a mix of anticipation and anxiety, aware that their status as the region's inaugural touring rugby team depended on the success of their travels. The team assembled in the city square on a sunny afternoon, with a crowd of curious spectators waiting for them to leave. Warbrick led the team onto the coach, a reliable vehicle that would transport them to the initial part of their trip. The team bid farewell to the crowd as they embarked on a journey that could define their legacies and influence the future of the sport in the region.

prefix: On April 15, 1991, Matthews and Langford appeared in federal court in Oregon, and both pleaded innocent to charges of conspiracy to commit murder and carrying out wiretapping. On April 25, 1991, Richard Kevin Langford pleaded guilty in federal court to participating in the murder conspiracy plot against Turner, and in exchange he received a sentence of five years in federal prison and the dismissal of other charges against him relating to firearms and wiretapping.
gold: Langford agreed to testify against the other members of the murder conspiracy. Langford wrote on his plea agreement form: "In 1985, meetings were held at the Rancho Rajneesh ... at which time the possible killing of the United States Attorney for Oregon was discussed. I participated in a number of these meetings and agreed with others to work toward that object." Prosecutor Timothy J. Reardon III stated that Langford had been a member of the Rajneesh commune in Oregon since it began in 1981, and that the government was able to prove he joined the murder conspiracy at a point in time after May 25, 1985. Reardon said that Langford was a member of a group called the "Circle of 38", which was the personal security force that guarded Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, and that he had served as a weapons instructor and policeman at the commune. Langford told U.S. District Judge Malcolm F. Marsh that he had suggested that guns for the murder conspiracy could be bought in Texas, instructed the conspirators about silencers, took responsibility for the weapons while they were in the commune, and disposed of them when members of the murder conspiracy decided to flee the U.S. for Europe. In July 1991, Carol Matthews, who did not offer any evidence against the others, entered an Alford plea indicating exactly what she did with her research, including dissuading Sheela, and was given a five-year sentence in federal court. She was the only one to serve a complete sentence and spent the longest amount of time in prison. Catherine Jane Stork was convicted of the attempted murder of Rajneesh's physician Dr. George Meredith (Swami Devaraj) in 1986, and served almost three years in jail. After her release, agents from the FBI uncovered the plot to assassinate Turner, but Stork had already fled to Germany. She was indicted by a federal grand jury in 1990. In 1991, the German government refused to extradite Stork back to the United States. In June 1991, U.S. prosecutors filed affidavits in the murder conspiracy case with the Higher Regional Court in Karlsruhe, Germany, as part of an attempt to extradite Catherine Jane Stork from Germany to the U.S.
text1:
Following Langford's guilty plea, the trial of Derrick Matthews continued. After a four-day trial, Matthews was found guilty on June 7, 1991, of conspiracy to commit murder and carrying out wiretapping. He was sentenced to 15 years in federal prison. The evidence presented at trial included testimony from co-conspirators and recordings of conversations between Matthews and Langford, which revealed their plans to murder Turner.

The motive behind the plot was attributed to a long-standing feud between Turner and Matthews, which stemmed from a business deal that had gone sour. Turner, a successful entrepreneur, had allegedly cheated Matthews out of a significant sum of money, leading to a deep-seated resentment and desire for revenge.

In the years that followed, both Matthews and Langford served their respective sentences, with Langford being released from federal prison in 1996. Matthews, however, would not be eligible for parole until 2006. The case served as a cautionary tale about the dangers of allowing personal vendettas to spiral out of control, and the devastating consequences that can result from such actions.
text2: As part of the deal, Langford became a key witness in the federal government's case against Stuart Matthews, and on June 24, 1991, Matthews was convicted of conspiracy to commit murder and wiretapping. His sentencing hearing was set for August, but before that took place, Matthews was found to be in possession of a small stash of marijuana in his jail cell, leading to additional charges of drug possession and distribution. Matthews was ultimately sentenced to an additional five years in federal prison, concurrent with his existing sentence, for a total of ten years. Langford, who had already begun his five-year sentence, finished his time in federal prison in September 1996, while Matthews remained behind bars until October 2002, when he was finally released after serving his full sentence.
text3: Langford played a crucial role in the federal government's case against Stuart Matthews, resulting in Matthews being convicted of conspiracy to commit murder and wiretapping on June 24, 1991. Matthews was found with marijuana in his jail cell before his sentencing hearing, resulting in additional drug-related charges. Matthews received a five-year sentence in addition to his existing sentence, bringing the total to ten years. Langford completed his five-year federal prison sentence in September 1996, while Matthews was released in October 2002 after serving his entire sentence.

prefix: He was almost a James Dean-like character." When Richmond was cast for a bit part in the 1983 movie Stroker Ace, "He fell right in with the group working on the film," said director Hal Needham.
gold: Cole Trickle, the main character in the movie Days of Thunder, played by Tom Cruise, was loosely based on Richmond and his interaction with Harry Hyde and Rick Hendrick. Richmond grew up in Ashland, Ohio. His parents, Al and Evelyn (née Warner) Richmond, met in the course of their work. Al was a welder for pipe construction companies and Evelyn was a field office manager. Noticing that highway crews had to dig up the entire highway to lay pipe, Al designed a machine to bore underneath the highway. To market this invention, he founded Richmond Manufacturing, which eventually exported machines worldwide. Tim's driving days started as a toddler when he was given a go-kart that he often drove inside buildings and across his lawn. He later raced the kart at tracks in Moreland and New Pittsburg. Richmond grew up in a well-to-do family, and was sometimes therefore treated differently by his classmates, so his parents enrolled him in Miami Military Academy in Miami, Florida. During his years in Miami, Tim and his mother moved to Florida and his father stayed in Ohio. While home in Ohio over a summer break, he met local drag racer Raymond Beadle through lifelong friend Fred Miller. When Richmond reached age 16, his parents purchased him a Pontiac Trans Am, a speedboat and a Piper Cherokee airplane for his birthday. Yet his mother Evelyn often worried about spoiling her only son. She once said, "Tim was lazy...", and "... I did everything for him. I ruined him, I admit it. He was my whole life." Richmond excelled in sports; he set a conference record in high hurdles and his high school football career was stellar enough that the academy retired his sports jersey after his gridiron days were over. Miami Military Academy named him Athlete of the Year in 1970. Richmond's other interests included flying, and he earned his private pilot license at age 16. Following high school graduation, Richmond attended Ashland University for about one year before dropping out. A friend of Richmond's father co-owned a sprint car and Richmond joined the team as a crew member for Dave Shoemaker. In 1976, 21-year-old Richmond took the car onto Lakeville Speedway at Lakeville, Ohio for some practice laps. "Somebody put a stopwatch on me," Richmond said. "I was running laps faster than Dave had been. It was the first time I had ever driven a race car."
text1: "His charisma and laid-back demeanor quickly made him a favorite among the cast and crew. Patric Standish, the film's leading man, recalled that Richmond would often show up on set with his guitar, breaking out into impromptu performances that would bring the entire production to a halt. Despite his relatively small role, Richmond's natural charm and effortless cool made him a scene-stealer, and he left a lasting impression on everyone involved in the film.
text2:
As the cameras rolled on the Stroker Ace set, Burt Reynolds, the film's star, took a liking to the young actor and decided to give him a bigger role. Reynolds, who was known for his philanthropic work and passion for nurturing young talent, saw something of himself in the young Richmond and decided to take him under his wing.

Before long, Richmond was earning more screen time and impressing the film's director, Hal Needham, with his raw talent and natural charisma. His scene-stealing performance caught the eye of Reynolds, who began mentoring him and introducing him to industry insiders.

"Old Burt saw something in me that nobody else did," Richmond would later recall in an interview. "He taught me how to be professional, how to work a crowd, and how to take care of myself. He became like a surrogate father to me."

The experience on Stroker Ace marked a turning point for Richmond's career, and Reynolds continued to champion him throughout his early years in Hollywood. The lessons he learned from Reynolds stayed with him throughout his own directing career, and he would often look back on that pivotal role as the moment when his big break began to take shape.
text3: While filming Stroker Ace, Burt Reynolds, the lead actor, grew fond of a young actor and chose to increase his role. Reynolds, known for his charitable efforts and dedication to mentoring new talent, felt a connection with young Richmond and decided to mentor him. Richmond quickly gained more on-screen opportunities and caught the attention of the director, Hal Needham, with his innate talent and charisma. Reynolds noticed his impressive performance and started mentoring him, introducing him to important people in the industry. Richmond later remembered in an interview that Burt Reynolds recognized something special in him that others didn't. He showed me the ropes of professionalism, crowd interaction, and self-care. He took on a fatherly role in my life. Richmond's career took a significant turn during his time on Stroker Ace, with Reynolds supporting him as he navigated his early years in Hollywood. He often reflected on the role as the starting point of his successful directing career, thanks to the valuable lessons he learned from Reynolds.

prefix: A third RAAF unit, No. 2 Squadron RAAF, flying Canberra bombers, was sent in 1967, and four RAN destroyers joined US patrols in the waters off North Vietnam.
gold: The Australian withdrawal effectively commenced in November 1970. As a consequence of the overall allied strategy of Vietnamization and with the Australian government keen to reduce its own commitment to the war, 8 RAR was not replaced at the end of its tour of duty. 1 ATF was again reduced to just two infantry battalions, albeit with significant armour, artillery and aviation support remaining. Australian combat forces were further reduced during 1971 as part of a phased withdrawal, and 1 ATF ceased operations in October. Meanwhile, the advisors remained to train South Vietnamese troops until withdrawn on 18 December 1972 by the newly elected Labor government of Gough Whitlam. The last Australian forces were finally withdrawn in 1973. The Vietnam War was Australia's longest and most controversial war and although initially enjoying broad support, as the nation's military involvement increased a vocal anti-war movement developed. More than 50,000 Australians served in Vietnam; 519 were killed and 2,398 were wounded. Four were awarded the Victoria Cross. Although the importance of 'joint' warfare had been highlighted during Second World War when Australian naval, ground and air units frequently served as part of single commands, the absence of a central authority continued to result in poor co-ordination between the services in the post-war era, with each organising and operating on the basis of a different military doctrine. The need for an integrated command structure received more emphasis during the Australian military's experiences in the Vietnam War. In 1973, the Secretary of the Department of Defence, Arthur Tange, submitted a report to the Government that recommended the unification of the separate departments supporting each service into a single department and the creation of the post of Chief of the Defence Force Staff. The Whitlam Labor Government subsequently amalgamated the five defence ministries (Defence, Navy, Army, Air Force, and Supply) into a single Department of Defence in 1973, while conscription under the National Service scheme was abolished. On 1 January 1976, the three branches of the Australian military were brought together as a unified, all-volunteer, professional force known as the Australian Defence Force (ADF). Today, the ADF is headquartered at Russell Offices in Canberra and is divided into Air, Land, Maritime and Special Operations Commands. In addition, Northern Command is based in Darwin, and is responsible for operations in Northern Australia. Until the 1970s, Australia's military strategy centred on the concept of Forward Defence, in which the role of Australian military and naval forces were to co-operate with Allied forces to counter threats in Australia's region.
text1:
By the end of 1967, Australia's military involvement in Vietnam had grown significantly, with over 4,000 personnel serving on the ground and in the air. In addition to No. 2 Squadron RAAF and the RAN destroyers, No. 9 Squadron RAAF, flying Iroquois helicopters, was also deployed to Vietnam. The helicopters were used to transport troops, supplies, and casualties, as well as conduct medical evacuations.

As the conflict escalated, the Australian government increased its commitment to the war effort. In 1968, the Australian Army's 1st Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (1 RAR) arrived in Vietnam, followed by 3 RAR in 1969. The two battalions were deployed to Phuoc Tuy Province, where they conducted operations against the Viet Cong and assisted in the construction of roads, bridges, and other infrastructure.

Australia's naval contribution also continued to grow, with the deployment of two more RAN destroyers, HMAS Hobart and HMAS Quadrant, in 1968. The ships joined US Navy and South Vietnamese naval vessels in patrolling the waters off North Vietnam and providing gunfire support to ground troops.

By the early 1970s, Australia's military involvement in Vietnam had peaked, with over 7,000 personnel serving in the country. The conflict took a heavy toll on Australian society, with opposition to the war growing and protests becoming more frequent. In 1972, the Australian government announced that it would withdraw its troops from Vietnam, and by 1973, all Australian combat troops had been withdrawn. However, Australia continued to provide military and economic aid to South Vietnam until the fall of Saigon in 1975.
text2:
In 1968, the Australian contribution to the war effort further expanded when a detachment of RAAF CH-47D Chinook helicopters arrived at Nui Diep, a base in southern South Vietnam, to support Australian troops operating in the region. The Chinooks provided vital airlift support, including transporting troops and supplies, and also conducted casualty evacuations.

Meanwhile, the RAN continued to play a key role in the naval aspect of the conflict, with its four destroyers joining other Allied warships in the Gulf of Tonkin to intercept and attack North Vietnamese naval forces. The Australians also contributed to the mining of the North Vietnamese ports of Haiphong and Hon Gay in an effort to restrict supplies reaching the communist forces.

Back in Australia, the debate over involvement in the conflict remained divisive, with many Australians opposing the government's decision to send troops to Vietnam. The movement against the war gained momentum, with widespread protest marches and civil unrest throughout the country. Despite these challenges, the Australian government maintained its commitment to the conflict, and its military personnel continued to play a crucial role in the fighting that would eventually claim the lives of over 500 Australian service members.
text3: In 1968, Australia increased their involvement in the war by sending RAAF CH-47D Chinook helicopters to Nui Diep in southern South Vietnam to assist Australian troops. The Chinooks played a crucial role in providing airlift support, transporting troops and supplies, and conducting casualty evacuations. At the same time, the Royal Australian Navy remained actively involved in the war by deploying its destroyers to the Gulf of Tonkin to engage North Vietnamese naval forces. Australia also participated in the mining of North Vietnamese ports to limit supplies to communist forces. The decision to send troops to Vietnam continued to spark controversy in Australia, with a significant portion of the population opposing the government's actions. Protests and civil unrest against the war escalated across the nation. Despite facing difficulties, the Australian government remained dedicated to the war, with their military personnel playing a vital role that resulted in the loss of more than 500 Australian service members.

prefix: The Marines seized documents, equipment and food supplies, destroyed the rest, and returned to the Lunga perimeter at 17:30. The quantities of supplies and intelligence from the captured documents revealed that at least 3,000 Japanese troops were on the island and apparently planning an attack.
gold: Edson and Colonel Gerald Thomas, Vandegrift's operations officer, believed that the Japanese attack would come at the Lunga Ridge, a narrow, grassy, long, coral ridge () parallel to the Lunga River just south of Henderson Field. The ridge offered a natural avenue of approach to the airfield, commanded the surrounding area and was almost undefended. Edson and Thomas tried to persuade Vandegrift to move forces to defend the ridge, but Vandegrift refused, believing that the Japanese were more likely to attack along the coast. Finally, Thomas convinced Vandegrift that the ridge was a good location for Edson's Raiders to "rest" from their actions of the preceding month. On 11 September, the 840 men of Edson's unit—including the 1st Raiders and the Paramarines—deployed onto and around the ridge and prepared to defend it. Kawaguchi's Center Body of troops was planning to attack the Lunga perimeter at the ridge, which they called "the centipede" (mukade gata) because of its shape. On 9 September, Kawaguchi's troops left the coast at Koli Point. Split into four columns, they marched into the jungle towards their predesignated attack points south and southeast of the airfield. Lack of good maps, at least one faulty compass, and thick, almost impenetrable jungle caused the Japanese columns to proceed slowly and zigzag, costing a lot of time. At the same time, Oka's troops approached the Lunga perimeter from the west. Oka had some intelligence on the Marine defenses, extracted from a U.S. Army pilot captured on 30 August. During the day of 12 September, Kawaguchi's troops struggled through the jungle toward their assembly points for that night's attacks. Kawaguchi wanted his three Center Body battalions in place by 14:00, but they did not reach their assembly areas until after 22:00. Oka was also delayed in his advance towards the Marine lines in the west. Only the Kuma battalion reported that they were in place on time. Despite the problems in reaching the planned attack positions, Kawaguchi was still confident in his attack plan because a captured U.S. pilot disclosed that the ridge was the weakest part of the Marine defenses. Japanese bombers attacked the ridge during daytime on 11–12 September, causing a few casualties, including two killed.
text1:
As the Marines returned to the Lunga perimeter, they were met with a sense of urgency and alertness. The intelligence gathered from the captured documents indicated a significant threat to the Allied forces on the island. General Alexander Vandegrift, the commander of the 1st Marine Division, immediately called a meeting with his senior officers to discuss the implications of the discovery.

"This changes everything," Vandegrift said, his voice low and serious. "We can't assume the Japanese are just going to sit back and wait for us to attack them. They're planning to attack us, and we need to be prepared."

The officers nodded in agreement, their minds racing with the possibilities. They knew that the Japanese were known for their aggressive tactics and were capable of launching a surprise attack at any moment.

Vandegrift continued, "We need to fortify our positions, increase patrols, and be prepared to respond quickly to any attack. I want our artillery to be ready to fire at a moment's notice, and our infantry to be prepared to move out at a moment's notice. We can't let the Japanese catch us off guard again."

The meeting ended with a sense of purpose and determination. The Marines knew that they were in for a tough fight, but they were confident in their training, their equipment, and their ability to work together as a team.

As the sun began to set on Guadalcanal, the Marines took up their positions, ready to face whatever the Japanese had in store for them. The sound of drums and bugles echoed through the jungle, a chilling reminder that the enemy was close, and the battle for Guadalcanal was far from over.
text2:
As the Marines debriefed and tallied their gains, the island's command realized the full extent of the Japanese force that had infiltrated the island. The captured documents revealed not only the number of troops but also their disposition, with multiple battalions concentrated near the island's west coast. The enemy's plan was to launch a surprise attack on the Marine positions, utilizing their superior numbers and unexpected location to gain an early advantage.

General Julian C. Smith, commander of the Marine forces on Guadalcanal, quickly mobilized his troops to prepare for the impending assault. The 1st Marine Regiment was redeployed from its positions on the island's eastern coast to the Lunga perimeter, where the bulk of the Japanese force was expected to strike. The 7th Marines and 11th Marines regiments were tasked with holding the lines, while the remaining troops from the 1st Marine Regiment formed a reserve force to be deployed as necessary.

Lieutenant General Alexander Vandegrift, commander of the Marine Expeditionary Force, hurried to Guadalcanal to coordinate the defense and assess the situation. As the darkness deepened on November 11, the Marines settled in for a long and potentially grueling fight, readying themselves for the dawn attack that was certain to come. The enemy's superior numbers gave him a strong advantage, but the Marines had their backs to the wall, and they were prepared to give their lives defending their tenuous foothold on the island. The stage was set for a desperate and bloody struggle, with the outcome of the battle hanging precariously in the balance.
text3: The island's command discovered the true size of the Japanese force after the Marines debriefed and counted their gains. The captured documents provided information on both the troop numbers and their locations, particularly noting the concentration of multiple battalions near the west coast of the island. The Japanese intended to catch the Marines off guard with a surprise attack, using their larger numbers and strategic positioning to their advantage. General Julian C. Smith swiftly organized his troops in anticipation of the imminent attack. The 1st Marine Regiment was moved from the eastern coast of the island to the Lunga perimeter in preparation for the anticipated attack by the main Japanese force. The 7th Marines and 11th Marines regiments were assigned to maintain the defense, with the rest of the 1st Marine Regiment serving as a backup force for deployment when needed. Lieutenant General Alexander Vandegrift rushed to Guadalcanal to oversee the defense and evaluate the circumstances. As night fell on November 11, the Marines prepared for a tough battle ahead, knowing that a dawn attack was inevitable. Despite being outnumbered, the Marines were ready to fight to the death to protect their position on the island. The battle was poised to be intense and uncertain, with the result hanging in the balance.

prefix: The 2011–12 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team represented the University of Michigan during the 2011–12 NCAA Division I men's basketball season. The team played its home games in Ann Arbor, Michigan at Crisler Center for the 45th consecutive year.
gold: It had a seating capacity of 12,721. It was also the team's 95th straight season as a member of the Big Ten Conference. Fifth-year head coach John Beilein led the team, alongside All-Big Ten players Trey Burke, Tim Hardaway, Jr. and Zack Novak. Burke was named Big Ten Freshman of the Year and was Michigan's first Associated Press All-American honoree since 1998. The team's season began with a preseason media day and practices in October 2011.
text1: The team was led by head coach John Beilein, who was in his sixth season at the helm. The Wolverines finished the regular season with a 24-10 overall record and a 13-5 record in the Big Ten Conference, good for a tie for second place. They earned a bid to the NCAA Tournament, where they were seeded fourth in the West Region. After defeating 13th-seeded Ohio in the first round, they faced 12th-seeded Temple in the second round, ultimately falling to the Owls by a score of 78-76 in overtime.
text2:
The team was led by sixth-year head coach John Beilein and featured a mix of veteran players and incoming freshmen. The roster included returning starters like Trey Burke, a junior point guard who was expected to lead the team in scoring and assists, and Jordan Morgan, a senior center who was a key force in the paint. The newcomers included freshmen like Trey Deshazior, a high-energy guard who was known for his defensive prowess, and Glenn Robinson III, a talented forward with a strong all-around game.

Off the court, the team was known for its commitment to academics, with several players earning All-Academic Big Ten honors during the previous seasons. The team also held a number of community service events throughout the year, including visits to local hospitals and schools, and a charity basketball tournament to benefit the University of Michigan's Mott Children's Hospital.

On the court, the Wolverines started off strong, winning their first nine games and earning a ranking in the top 10 of the Associated Press and USA Today Coaches polls. They went on to win their first 13 games, including a thrilling 67-64 overtime victory over rival Ohio State in late January. However, the team struggled with inconsistent play throughout the rest of the season, dropping several close games and failing to win any of their last four Big Ten conference games.

Despite the ups and downs, the Wolverines finished the regular season with a respectable 24-10 record and earned a berth in the National Invitation Tournament (NIT). In the NIT, the team advanced to the semifinals, where they fell to the eventual champion, Stanford University, in a close 71-64 contest.

Looking ahead to the next season, the Wolverines would return a strong core group of players, including Burke, Morgan, and Robinson III, and would look to build on the momentum gained during the 2011-2012 campaign.
text3: John Beilein, a sixth-year head coach, led a team with a combination of experienced players and new freshmen. The team had familiar faces like Trey Burke and Jordan Morgan, who were expected to play key roles in scoring and defense. Newcomers to the team included high-energy guard Trey Deshazior and talented forward Glenn Robinson III. The team was recognized for their dedication to academics, with multiple players receiving All-Academic Big Ten accolades in past years. In addition to their academic achievements, the team participated in various community service activities such as hospital visits, school visits, and a charity basketball tournament for Mott Children's Hospital. The Wolverines had a successful start to the season, winning their first nine games and securing a spot in the top 10 rankings of both the Associated Press and USA Today Coaches polls. They continued their winning streak by defeating Ohio State in a close overtime game in late January, extending their undefeated record to 13 games. Despite their early success, the team faced challenges with inconsistent performance in the latter part of the season, losing multiple close games and failing to secure victories in their final four Big Ten conference matchups. The Wolverines ended the regular season with a solid 24-10 record and qualified for the National Invitation Tournament (NIT) despite facing challenges. Michigan made it to the NIT semifinals but lost to Stanford University in a close game. The Wolverines planned to capitalize on the progress made in the previous season by retaining key players like Burke, Morgan, and Robinson III for the upcoming season.

prefix: On 22 April, Chinese forces attacked the Kapyong valley and forced the South Korean defenders to withdraw. Australian and Canadian troops were ordered to halt this Chinese advance.
gold: After a night of fighting the Australians recaptured their positions, at the cost of 32 men killed and 59 wounded. In July 1951, the Australian battalion became part of the combined Canadian, British, Australian, New Zealand, and Indian 1st Commonwealth Division. The second major battle took place during Operation Commando and occurred after the Chinese attacked a salient in a bend of the Imjin River. The 1st Commonwealth Division counter-attacked on 3 October, capturing a number of objectives including Hill 355 and Hill 317 during the Battle of Maryang San; after five days the Chinese retreated. Australian casualties included 20 dead and 104 wounded. The belligerents then became locked in static trench warfare akin to the First World War, in which men lived in tunnels, redoubts, and sandbagged forts behind barbed wire defences. From 1951 until the end of the war, 3 RAR held trenches on the eastern side of the division's positions in the hills northeast of the Imjin River. Across from them were heavily fortified Chinese positions. In March 1952, Australia increased its ground commitment to two battalions, sending 1 RAR. This battalion remained in Korea for 12 months, before being replaced by 2 RAR in April 1953. The Australians fought their last battle during 24–26 July 1953, with 2 RAR holding off a concerted Chinese attack along the Samichon River and inflicting significant casualties for the loss of five killed and 24 wounded. Hostilities were suspended on 27 July 1953. 17,808 Australians served during the war, with 341 killed, 1,216 wounded and 30 captured. The Malayan Emergency was declared on 18 June 1948, after three estate managers were murdered by members of the Malayan Communist Party (MCP). Australian involvement began in June 1950, when in response to a British request, six Lincolns from No. 1 Squadron and a flight of Dakotas from No. 38 Squadron arrived in Singapore to form part of the British Commonwealth Far East Air Force (FEAF). The Dakotas were subsequently used on cargo runs, troop movement, as well as paratroop and leaflet drops, while the Lincoln bombers carried out bombing raids against the Communist Terrorist (CT) jungle bases. The RAAF were particularly successful, and in one such mission known as Operation Termite, five Lincoln bombers destroyed 181 communist camps, killed 13 communists and forced one into surrender, in a joint operation with the RAF and ground troops.
text1:
As the Chinese forces pushed deep into the Kapyong valley, the Australian and Canadian troops, positioned on the high ground overlooking the valley, prepared to engage the enemy. The Australians, led by the 27th British Commonwealth Brigade, took up positions on the left flank, while the Canadians, of the 27th Brigade Group, occupied the center and right flank. The troops were well-equipped and well-trained, but they were vastly outnumbered, with estimates suggesting the Chinese had over 30,000 soldiers against their 6,000.

At dawn on 24 April, the Chinese launched a massive assault on the Australian positions, supported by artillery and mortar fire. The Australians, dug in behind their earthworks, held firm against the initial waves of Chinese troops, but the pressure was relentless. The Australians fought back with small arms, machine guns, and artillery, but they were being pushed back slowly.

Meanwhile, on the Canadian flank, the Chinese had launched a series of probing attacks, testing the defenses and searching for weaknesses. The Canadians, well-entrenched behind their own earthworks, were holding firm, but they knew they couldn't hold out for much longer against the sheer weight of numbers.

Despite being vastly outnumbered, the Australian and Canadian troops held their ground, buying precious time for the South Korean forces to regroup and reorganize. The two brigades fought with remarkable courage and tenacity, repelling wave after wave of Chinese attacks, and inflicting heavy casualties on the enemy. As the day wore on, the Chinese began to falter, their advance slowing and then halting. The Australians and Canadians had held the line, saving the day and preserving the integrity of the United Nations Command's defense.
text2:
As the Chinese troops pushed forward, the Australian 28th Battalion, led by Lieutenant Colonel Howard Kendall, positioned itself on the dominant ground at Charter Hill, overlooking the Kapyong River and the road to Seoul. The battalion was tasked with holding the Chinese at all costs, knowing that if the river was breached, the Chinese would roll over the South Korean defenders and into the city.

Meanwhile, the Canadian 2nd Battalion, The Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry (PPCLI), took up positions on the Australians' left flank, facing the rugged and heavily wooded terrain north of the river. The PPCLI had recently been alerted to the Chinese attack and was quickly deployed to support the Australians in slowing down the Chinese advance.

As night fell, the Chinese resumed their assault, launching wave after wave of soldiers against the Australian and Canadian lines. The Australians, with their experience fighting Japan in the Second World War, were prepared and well-trained to hold out against the Chinese attack. They dug in deep, using entrenching tools to prepare defensive positions, and waited for the Chinese to come to them.

On their right flank, the PPCLI faced a more challenging situation. The dense forest and rugged terrain made it difficult for them to establish clear fields of fire, and they had to rely heavily on camouflage, concealment, and clever tactics to hold off the Chinese attack. Despite these challenges, the PPCLI held firm, using their training and combat experience to adapt to the changing circumstances and keep their lines intact.
text3: The Australian 28th Battalion, under the leadership of Lieutenant Colonel Howard Kendall, took a strategic position on Charter Hill as Chinese troops advanced towards Seoul. The battalion had the crucial mission of preventing the Chinese from crossing the river, as it was understood that if they succeeded, the South Korean defenders would be overrun and Seoul would be at risk. At the same time, the Canadian 2nd Battalion, The Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry (PPCLI), positioned themselves on the left side of the Australians, preparing to face the rough and densely forested area to the north of the river. The PPCLI was promptly mobilized to assist the Australians in delaying the Chinese offensive after being informed of the attack. During the night, the Chinese continued their attack by sending multiple waves of soldiers against the Australian and Canadian positions. The Australians were well-equipped to withstand the Chinese assault due to their prior combat experience against Japan in World War II. They dug deep and prepared defensive positions with entrenching tools, anticipating the arrival of the Chinese troops. The PPCLI encountered a tougher situation on their right side. The challenging landscape forced them to use camouflage, concealment, and strategic maneuvers to defend against the Chinese assault. The PPCLI remained resilient, utilizing their expertise and experience to adjust to the evolving situation and maintain their defensive positions.

prefix: This marked a rise in the ratings from the previous episode, "Garage Sale", which can be attributed to Ferrell's guest appearance.
